div.p: EXPERIMENTS AND Coniderations ABOUT THE Poroity of Bodies, IN TWO ESSAYS.
By the Honourable ROBERT BOYLE, Fellow of the Royal Society.
LONDON, Printed for Sam. Smith at the Prince's Arms in S. Pauls Church-Yard. 1684.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
THe Reader is to be advertis'd, not to expect in the following Eay a Regular, or o much as a Coherent, Dicoure. For it was intended only as a collection of looe Experiments and Obervations about the Poroity of the parts of Bodies belonging as Chymits peak) to the Animal Kingdom, and laid (not to ay thrown (together, in order to what I had thoughts of offering, towards an Intelligible account of Occult Qualities. I am not ignorant, that even one of the mot ancient and famous of Phyicians hath aid, that a mans body is
(almot) every where perpirable. But I judg'd that a Doctrine of uch moment, and which divere things in the Theory and Practice of after Phyicians may make one think they either disbelieved or diregarded, did not deerve to be lightly deliver'd, and in general terms, but to be more narrowly conidered, and likewie made out by Particular Intances, whoe applyablenes and uefulnes to explain divers obcure Phaenomena, may hereafter appear much greater, then perchance at the firt ight they will be thought.

And the foregoing advertiement, with a light change, which 'tis preum'd the Reader may eaily make of • imelf, is to be extended to the Eay tacked to this about the Pores of Solid Bodies, and o may excue the abence of a ditinct Preface to it.

div.head: An Eay of the POROUSNESS OF ANIMAL BODIES.
div.p:
AS the mot numerous part of the Pores of Bodies is too minute to be een, o the Contemplation of them has been thought too inconiderable to be regarded. But when I conider, how much mot of the Qualities of Bodies, and conequently their operations depend upon the tructure of their minute, and ingly inviible, particles, and that to this latent contexture, the¯ bignes the figure and the collocation of the Intervals and Pores
do necearily concur with the Size, Shape and Dipoition or contrivance of the ubtantial parts I cannot but think the Doctrine of the mall Pores of Bodies, of no mall importance to Natural Philoophy. And I carce doubt, but if uch little things had not ecaped the ight of our Illutrious Verulam, he would have afforded a good Porology (if I may o call it) a place, (and perhaps not the lowet neither,) among his Deiderata.

And, though other imployments and avocations hinder me from attempting to treat of this ubject as amply and particularly as it deerveth, or even as I had deign'd in a Scheme drawn divere years ince, and een by ome Virtuoi; Yet, not to leave apart of Phyicks, that eems to me o curious and important, altogether as uncultivated as I found it; I hall preent you as many of the Notes I had drawn together about this ubject, as I can conveniently (for I do not pretend to do it methodically) reduced to three heads: Whereof the firt, which
will challenge to it elf this preent eay, is the poroity of Animal Bodies, about which I hall not be olicitous to marhal my obervations, ince they all conpire to hew but this one thing; That the parts of Animals, epecially whilet thee are alive, are furnihed with numerous Pores.

Thoe parts of the Bodies of Animals, wherein their poroity may be bet hewn eem to be their Membranes or Skins, the Bones, the Fleh, and Coagmentations of Membranes, Fleh and Juices. And therefore it would be proper enough to treat of thee Heads ditinctly, and give Intances of each of them in particular. But yet I think it will be more convenient, to et down in order the principal Fountains, whence the Porounes of the ubtances belonging to the Animal Kingdom (as the Chymits peak) may be derived, and to annex to each of thee the Experiments and obervations, upon which I argue from it, and which it will be eay to refer, if
that be thought fit, to this or that of the parts above mentioned (namely the Membranes, Bones, &c.) whereto they hall (repectively) appear the mot properly to belong.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p:
THe firt thing from which I will deduce the Poroity we have been peaking of, is, the Frame or Contitution of the table Parts of the Bodies of Animals. For the Body of an Animal being not a rude and indigeted lump of matter, but a curious engine, admirably framed and contrived for the exercie of everal Functions as Nutrition, Generation, Senation, and many differing local Motions, it was neceary that it hould be furnihed with variety of Diimilar and Organical parts not only very Skilfully, but very differingly, contrived congruous to the everal ues for which they were deigned, or if you pleae, to the everal Functions they
were to perform. And, becaue 'twill be eaily granted, that the Corpucles, that are skilfully brought together for uch purpoes, mut be o contexed as not to touch one another exactly every where, it will readily follow that they mut leave little Intervals or Pores between them, and that, conidering the multitude of particles that mut go to the making up the Body of the Animal, and the great difference and variety in point of bignes and figure of the Corpucles that are requiite to contex uch differing parts, as Membranes, Fibres Bones, Grizles, Ligaments, Veins, Arterys, Nerves, &c. Both the number and the variety of the Pores cannot but be very great. This argument will be much confirmed, by what there will be occaion to ay further to the ame purpoe, in the Eay touching the Poroity of even Solid Bodies. Wherefore I hall now proceed to the Second thing, whence we may derive that of Animal Subtances.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p:
THis is afforded us by conidering the Nutrition of Animals. For there being continually a great wate made of their ubtance, partly by the excluion of viible excrements, and partly by the avolation of inviibles team, this great los mut necearily from time to time be repairpaired by the upplies afforded by Nutrition of which the bet, if not the only Intelligible, way of giving an account, is, to conceive that the alimental Juice, prepared chiefly in the Stomach is impelled or attracted (for to our preent purpoe it matters not which) to the parts of the Body that are to be nourihed by it, and the Corpucles of the juice ininuate themelves at thoe Pores they find commenurate to their Bignes, and Shape; and thoe that are mut congruous, being aimilated, add to the ubtance of the part wherein
they ettle, and o make amends for the Conumption of thoe that were lot by that part before. This may be illutrated by what happens in Plants, and epecially Trees, in which, of the various Corpucles that are to be found in the liquors, that moiten the Earth, and are agitated by the heat of the Sun and the Air, thoe that happen to be commenurate to the Pores of the Root, are by their Intervention impelled into it, or imbibed by it, and thence conveyed to the other parts of the Tree in the form of Sap which paing through new trainers, (whereby its Corpucles are eparated, and prepared or fitted to be detained in everal parts) receives the alterations requiite to the being turned into Wood, Bark, Leaves, Blooms, Fruit, &c. But to return to Animals, our argument from their Nutrition will be much confirmed, by conidering, that in Children and in other young Animals, that have not yet attained their due Stature and Bulk, the Nutrition is o copious as to amount
to a continu'd Augmentation. For, as 'tis evident that Animals grow in all their parts, and each part according to all its Dimenions, in o much that even the cavities of Bones increae; o we cannot well conceive how this can be done, unles the Nutritive liquor be ditributed through the whole Body of the part that is to be nourihed and augmented. And to this ditribution 'tis requiite that the Body abound with Pores into which the congruous particles of the Juice may be intimatly admitted, & penetrating even into the innermot recees, may place or lodge themelves in the manner that is mot convenient for the Natural Increae of the part. But the more particular Declaration of this Proces I leave to Anatomits and Phyicians.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
HAving premis'd once for all, that in this Eay, I often ue the word Skin in the lax and popular ene of it,
without nicely ditinguihing the Epidermis or Cuticula, called in Englih the Scarf-skin, from the Cutis it invets and ticks cloely to; I hall proceed to another Topic, whence the Porounes of Animals may be argued, namely, the great plenty of matter that is daily carried off by Sweat, and inenible Tranpiration. For, 'tis confet that Sweat is dicharged at the Pores of the skin; and ince there is no penetration of Dimenions, we may afely conclude, that the matter that is not wated by Sweat, or by any other enible way of evacuation, mut have mall Pores or out-lets in the Skin, at which it may iue in the form of teams; though nothing hinders but that inviible Effluvia alo may evaporate at the ame Pores with the Sweat, though for want of plenty or grones, or a fit dipoition in the ambient, thoe Effluvia be not at the Orifices of thoe Pores brought into little Drops, uch as thoe of weat.

That therefore the Skins of a multitude of Animals, though they eem
cloe to the eye, may be porous, may (as we have been aying) be argued in many of them from their weating. But becaue all of them have not been oberved to weat, as is wont to be particularly affirmed of Dogs, we hall add ome other Intances to make it probable.

We may ometimes, in the mooth skin of a living man, dicern Pores with good Microcopes, and, with one that is none of the bet, we may eaily on the inide of gloves, which are made but of skins dret, dicern good tore of thee little out-lets: Sometimes orderly enough ranged to make the ight not unpleaant. And though ome of them may, I think, be upected to have been made by the Hairs that grew on the skin before 'twas dret, yet that greater numbers of them, than can be uppoed to come from thence, are perforations that pas quite through the Leather, may, not improbably, be hewn by the uual Practice of Chymits, to purify Quick-ilver by tying it up trictly
in a piece of kids or heeps Leather, and then wringing it hard to force it out; by which means the lower urface of the Leather will be covered with a Mercurial Dew or Sweat which will fall down and fly out, as the Pores happen to open this or that way, in a thick hower of globules, leaving the dros behind in the Leather. And tho when a mans skin is tanned it is of a greater thicknes then one would expect, and that which I employed eem'd almot as thick as a Buck-skin Glove yet having had the curioity to try the ame Experiment with the skin of a mans Arm, I found the Quick-Silver would be queez'd out at the Pores of that alo. 'Tis not neceary that I hould here inquire, whether the little holes, unperceiv'd by the naked Eye, at which the Sweat is dicharged, and perhaps the matter that the Body looes by inenible tranpiration gets out, be not, at leat mot of them, the Orifices of mall excretory veels, belonging to thoe very numerous glandules which the excellent Anatomits
Steno and Malpighi are aid to have dicovered beneath the Cuticula, and which for their malnes and hape have been called Glandulae miliares. I need not, I ay, engage in this inquiry, ince according to this ingenious opinion alo, the Skin mut be allow'd a multitude of mall Perforations or Pores, and that is ufficient for my purpoe, from whenceoever this Poroity proceeds in a mans Skin. For the next obervation will hew that ome membranes of Animals may give paage to tranpir'd matter without being perforated by the excretou • Veels of Glandules.

The Membranes or Skins under the hells of Hens Eggs, though they be very thin, are of a Contexture very fine and cloe as may be confirmed by their reiting the harp Corpucles of Vinegar; and yet, that not only thee Skins, but the hells that cover them, are porous, may be inferred from the Experiments I made, of keeping them upended for a good while, and carefully counterpoied in good cales;
for by thee it appeared, that the Eggs did from time to time manifetly loe in weight; which could not reaonably be imputed but to an inviible Tranpiration, the rather, becaue uually in eggs that have been kept long, there will be at one end a cavity which is wont to increae with their age, and is made by the hrinking of the Membrane from the Shell, to accommodate it elf to the diminihed quantity of matter, that remains to be involved by it.

When I conider the plenty of matter, that is wont to be dicharged daily by inenible Perpiration, epecially in Healthful men that exercie themelves moderately, I cannot but think it probable, that the minute Pores, that uffice for the carrying off o much matter, are very numerous, and are much more o than even by the multitude of drops of weat, that erve to wet the skin, men are wont to imagine. For Sanctorius in his excellent little Tract de Medicina tatica affirms, that what is barely carryed
off by inenible tranpiration does ordinarily amount to more, that is, diminihes more the weight of a mans Body, than all the viible excrements (whether gros or liquid) put together. Aph. vi. He adds, If the meat and Drink, taken in one day, amount to the weight of eight pound, the inenible Tranpiration ordinarily amounts to five pounds or thereabouts. And elewhere ays, that ometimes in the pace of 24 hours, in the Winter time, a healthy Body may exhale fifty ounces or more. And ome Tryals, that I have carefully made upon my elf, added to ome others of a very curious as well as great Prince, that made ue of a like intrument, & did me the honour to acquaint me with the events, gave me no caue to reject Sanctorius obervations, conidering the difference in point of heat, between the climate of Italy, where he writ, and that of England, where ours were made; only I fear, there has been committed an overight by thoe many that acribe all the decrement of
weight, that is not referrable to the groer Excrements, to what tranpires at the Pores of the viible parts of the skin, without taking notice of that great plenty of teams that is in expirations dicharged through the Windpipe by the Lungs, and appear manifet to the Eye it elf in froty weather; though they may be preumed to be then les copious than thoe Inviible ones that are emitted in Summer, when the ambient Air is much warmer. But though I look upon the Windpipe as the great Chimney of the Body in comparion of thoe little Chimneys (if I may o call them) in the Skin, at which the matter that is wated by perpiration is emitted, yet the number of thee little vents is o very great, that the fuliginous Exhalations that teal out at them, cannot but be very coniderable. Beides that, thoe that are dicharged at the Apera Arteria, do probably, at leat for the mot part, iue out at the latent Pores of the Membranes that invet the Lungs; which membranes
may be lookt upon as external parts of the Body, in reference to the air, tho not in reference to our ight. But, to return to our Eggs, we may afely allow a very great evacuation to be made at the Pores of the skin in man, who is a anguineous and hot Animal, ince we ee that even Eggs, that are till actually cold, tranpire. And I elewhere mention the copious tranpiration even of Frogs, that are always cold to the touch; and the Decrement in weight of ome Animals, oon after they are trangled or uffocated, when, their vital Heat being extinct, no more fumes are emitted by expirations at the wind-Pipe: To which igns may be added the trivial experiment of holding in warm weather the palp of ones Finger, as near as one can without contact, to ome cold & olid mooth body, as to a piece of polihed Steel or Silver; for you will often times ee this Body preently ullyed or overcat, with the inviible teams that iue out of the Pores of the Finger, and are by the cold and mooth
urface of the Body condened into viible teams, that do as 'twere cloud that urface, but upon the Removal of the Finger, quickly fly off, and leave it bright again.

The Perviounes of the skin outwards may not improbably be argued from the quicknes wherewith ome Medicines take away ome black and blew Dicolorations of the skin, that happen upon ome lighter troke, or other contuions. For, ince thee preternatural and unightly colours are wont by Phyicians to be imputed to ome mall portions of blood, that upon the contuion is forced out of the capillary veels that lye beneath the urface of it, & being extravaated are obliged to tagnate there; it eems very likely, that if a powerful Medicine do quickly remove the dicoloration, that work is performed by attenuating, and diolving, and agitating the matter, and dipoing it to tranpire through the cutaneous Pores, though perhaps, when 'tis thus changed, ome part of it may be imbibed again by
the Capillary Veels, and o by the circulation carryed into the mas of Blood. Now, that there are Medicines that will peedily work upon uch black and blew marks, the Books and Practice of Phyicians and Chirurgeons will oblige us to admit. Helmont talks much of the great vertue of white Briony root in uch caes. And a notable Experiment made a while ago by a Learned acquaintance of mine in an odd cae, did not give Helmont the Lye. And I know an eminent Peron, who having ome while ince received a troke, by a kick of an Hore, on his Leg, a very threatning contuion, which made the part look black and frightful, he was in a few hours cured of the pain of the hurt, and freed from the black part of the Dicoloration by the bare application of the chopt leaves of Hiop mixt with freh Butter into the form of a Pultes.

Nor is it only the Skin that covers the viible parts of the Body that we judg to be thus porous, but in the Membranes
that invet the internal parts, we may reaonably uppoe both numerous and very various Pores, according to the exigency of their peculiar and different Functions or Offices. For, the two firt caues of Poroity mention'd in this Eay, are as well applicable to the Membranes that cover the internal parts, as the Liver, the Spleen, &c. as to the external Skin, or Membrane that covers the Limbs; and in ome repects the tranpiration through uch Pores eems more advantaged, than that through the Pores of the urface of the Body; ince the parts that environ the Spleen, Liver, Kidneys, &c. in man, are hot in comparion of the ambient Air, and being alo wet, which the Air is not, the laxity of the Pores of the internal parts is doubly befriended. And perhaps it may be allowable to conceive, both the Skin that covers the Limbs, and the Membranes that invet the internal parts of the Body, to be like worted tockings, Wat-Coats, &c. Which in their

ordinary tate have a kind of continuity, but upon occaion can have their Pores every way enlarged and tretched, in this or that manner, as the Agents that work on them determine them to be. This may be confirmed, by what we manifetly ee in the finer ort of leather, as that of Kid or Lamb, and by the latent Pores that may be opened in Sheeps-Leather, and mans Leather, by the preure of included Quick-Silver.

This Poroity of a living mans Skin and other Membranes, though internal ones, will the more eaily be aented to if it appear that uch thick and gros Membranes, as the urinary bladders of dead Animals, are Porous and Penetrable even by Water. This we tryed, by putting ome alt of Tartar in a clean well dryed bladder (which ought to be afterwards tyed up cloe in the neck, let the effect hould be acribed to the moit Air) and leaving the lower part of the bladder, as far as the Salt, reached immered in common Water, whoe particles
by degrees ininuated themelves into the Pores of the bladder, in plenty enough to reolve the Salt of Tartar into a liquor. And, that it may not be aid that the Acrimony of the Salt, by fretting the bladder, made way for the Corpucles of the Water, I hall add that the Experiment ucceeded, but much more lowly, when we tryed it with Sugar intead of Salt of Tartar. And there are ome, who pretend that certain Syrups made this lovenly way, which they would have pas for a ecret, are very much preferable to thoe made of common Water.

That the films that line the hells of Eggs are of a very cloe Contexture eems probable, as by other things, o by their reiting ome liquors, harp enough to corrode the hell, and yet that uch Membranes are pervious to Liquors that are none of the mot ubtile of all, we found by the enuing Experiment. This was made by taking an ordinary Hens Egg, and keeping it for two or three days in ditill'd Vinegar,
or in trong crude Vinegar. For then taking it out of the Liquor and wiping it well, it was viibly, and not inconiderably, well'd, which I concluded to be from the ingres of ome particles of the liquors, at the Pores of the Skins that invet the White of the Egg. For we found nothing broken, though we made the Tryal more than once. And to be atisfied that the manifet expanion proceeded from ome other caue, than the meer dilatation of the White, or Yolk, or both, we compared the weight of the Egg, after it was taken out and well wiped, with that which had been taken before 'twas put into the Mentruum, and found the Egg, notwithtanding the los of the Shell, to be coniderably heavier than 'twas before its immerion.

I hall add on this occaion that by a more unlikely way than that newly recited, both the Egg, Shell and Lining of an Egg, may be penetrated. For, notwithtanding the fine and cloe contexture of the Membranes that invet
the Eggs, the Chinees have a way of Salting them in the hell, as I have been aured both by Englih and Dutch Merchants trading to the Eat Indies. And in one of the Dutch Journals ent by the Council of Batavia to their Principals in Holland, and intercepted by an Englih man of War, I met with divers accounts of great numbers of alted Eggs, that were uch or uch a day of uch a Month brought in by Sea to Batavia or other Ports. Long after which time, meeting with an ingenious Phyician, that liv'd in Batavia, I learned by enquiry from him, that 'tis very true that uch Eggs are frequently met with in thoe parts; he having divers times eaten of them there: ome that he judged to have been either boyled or roated, before they were alted; and others that were raw, when they came to be dreed for him, but yet retained a Briny tat. And, though the Merchants I enquired of could not tell me what way the Chinees employed to Salt their Eggs, without making them
unfit for common ue, yet by a tryal made with clay and Brine, in which I kept the Eggs for a competent time, I was perwaded that 'twas poible the Chinees hould have the Art acribed to them. For upon the breaking of an Egg coated with clay, after it had lain for a competent time in Brine, I found its Tat coniderably Salt, but was, by I know not what accident, hindered from proecuting the Experiment, and endeavouring to make it more practicable and ueful.

I knew a Phyitian of more learning than vertue, who, being tormented with a violent and obtinate Colic of a peculiar kind, was wont to relieve himelf by Cliters of Sack; thô he uually found that not long after he had taken any of them, they would make him giddy, and fuddle him, as he himelf confeed to me. But upon this Intance I lay not much weight, and les upon what was anwered me by a great Chirurgeon, who having practied his Art in the Wet-Indies, and being asked
by me whether he had not dreed Wounds and Ulcers with the recent juice of Tobacco (a plant I ue to keep growing in my Garden for its excellent vertues in cuts, burns, and tumors;) and whether, if he employed it, he did not find it emetick, he told me among other things, that having Divers times dreed with this Juice a mall Ulcer in a Womans leg, the patient oon after the application would grow ick, and have her tomack turned, or actually vomit. But, as I was aying, on this intance I lay no tres, becaue the Corpucles of the Tobacco might probably enough get in at the mall Orifices of ome corroded Veels, and o be conveyed inwards, rather by the help of the Circulation of the blood, than on the account of the Porounes of the Parts. And therefore I hall rather mention what has been related to me, by an eminent Phyician of the famous Colledge of London, namely, that he had divers times given himelf a vomit, by a certain application of decocted Tobacco to
his writs, and ome other external parts; which brings into my mind, what is affirmed to have been oberved in ome Children that have cabb'd Heads, who have been made Drunk, by the application of Clothes or punges wetted in Infuion of Tobacco, or of trong Liquors, and applied to the part affected. Though in this cae the inebriating Particles may be upected to have got in, not at the meer Pores, but rather at the Orifices of the Capillary Veels, that were made acceible by uch little olutions of Continuity, as are eldom wanting in cabbed Heads.

That Children may be purged by outward applications is aerted by ome Phyicians; and an experienced Peron of that number has affirmed to me, that he can almot contantly do it by a Plaiter. But 'tis more coniderable what was related to me by an eminent Virtuoo, who being indipoed to believe uch things a while before he told me the tory, was deired by a curious Peron to hew him
his Hand which the Relator having done the other took it in his hand, which was moitened (as was afterwards confeed) with a kind of ubtile Chymical Oil, but o lightly, that the Relator carce minded it, till ome time after when he found himelf pret with a motion, like that which a purge would have given him; for the other thereupon miling, my acquaintance began to upect what the matter might be, and was in a hort time purged four times, without griping, or other pain or dicompoure. But to return to the Porounes of Membranes, it may erve to make way for your admitting it, to oberve, that though Lute-trings be but Ropes of Fibres (which are at leat the chief parts that Membranes conit of) dead, cold and tiff, yet when the lute is in tune they will ometimes in wet weather well o forcibly as with noie and violence to break, which proceeds from the copious ingres of moit vapors into their Pores, whereby they are not only hortened, but as I have tryed in
nice cales, made manifetly heavier.

The Poroity of the internal parts of Animals by both the foremention'd ways (viz. of emiion and reception of Corpucles,) may be confirmed by the things that happen in ome of the Metataes or Tranlations (as the Phyitians call them) of the morbifick matter in dieaed Bodies. 'Tis known to them that are any thing converant with Hopitals, or the obervations of Phyicians, that there do not eldom occur in Dieaes udden Removes of the matter that caued them, from one part to another according to the nature and functions of which, there may emerge a new Dieae, more or les dangerous than the former, as the invaded part is more or les noble. Thus oftentimes the matter, which in the anguiferous Veels produced a Feaver, being dicharged upon ome internal parts of the Head, produces a Delirium or Phrenitis; in the latter of which I have omewhat wondered, to ee the Patients Water o like that of a Peron without a Feaver; the ame
Febrile matter either by a deviation of Nature, or medicines improper or unskillfully given, is dicharged ometimes upon the Pleura, or Membrane that lines the ides of the Chet; ometimes upon the throat; ometimes upon the Guts; and caues in the firt cae a Pleuriie, in the 2d a Squinancy, and in the third a Flux, for the mot part dyenterical. But, becaue I uppoe, that many, if not mot, of thee tranlations of peccant humors, are made by the help of the circulation of the Blood, I forbore at the beginning of this Section to peak in general terms, when I mentioned them in reference to the Porounes of the internal parts of the Body, and contented my elf to intimate, that ome of them may erve to confirm that Poroity.

This will not perhaps eem improbable, if we conider that 'tis in effect already proved, by the ame arguments by which we have hewn, that both the Skin and the internal Membranes are furnihed with Pores, Permeable by Particles whoe Shape and
Size are correpondent to them. For we may thence probably deduce, that when a morbifick matter, whether in the form of Liquor, or of exhalations, chances to have Corpucles uited to the Pores of this or that part of the Body, it may, by a concoure of Circumtances, be determined to invade it, and o dilodge from its former receptacle, and excite Diorders in the part it removes to.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: ANother thing whence the Poroity of Animals may be argued is, their taking in of Effluvia from without. For thee cannot get into the internal parts of the Body, to perform their operations there, without penetrating the Skin, and conequently entring the Pores of it.
Now, That things, outwardly applyed to the Body, may without wounding the Skin, be convey'd to the internal parts, there are many things that argue.

And firt, it has been oberved in ome Perons, (for all are not equally dipoed to admit the action of particular Poyons) that Cantharides, being externally apply'd by Chyrurgions or Phyicians, may oon, and before they break the Skin, produce great diorders in the Urinary Paages, and ometimes caue bloody Water. And I remember, that having once had a blitering Plaiter, applyed by a skilful Chyrurgion between my houlders, though I knew not that there were any Cantharides at all mixt with the other Ingredients, yet it gave me about the neck of my Bladder one of the eniblet pains I had ever felt, and forced me to end for help at a very uneaonable time of night.

The Porounes of the Skin may be alo argued from divers of the effects even of Milder Plaiters. For, though ome Plaiters may operate as they cloely tick to the Skin, and hinder Perpiration from within, and fence the part from the external cold; yet, twill carce be denied, that
many of them have notable effects upon other accounts, whereof none is o likely and coniderable as the copious ingres of the Corpucles of the Plaiter, that enter at the Pores of the Skin, and being once got in, act according to their repective Natures & Vertues. The like may be aid of Ointments, whoe operations, epecially on Children (whoe Skin is ordinarily more oft and lax) are ometimes very notable. And I have known coniderable things performed by them, in an internal Dieae of grown men, where I hould carce have expected a Vegetable Ointment hould perform o much: I ay, a Vegetable Ointment, for 'tis vulgarly known that by Mercurial Ointments Salivation may be excited; and ometimes, againt the Phyitians will, the Corpucles of the Quick Silver get o far into the Body, that he is not able to get them out again.

What we lately aid of Plaiters, may be applyed to thoe that Phyitians call Pericarpia, or Writ-bands:
The better ort of which, though ometimes ineffectual, are oftentimes uccesful in topping Fits of Agues, as I have frequently found in a mixture, elewhere mention'd, of Currans, Hops, Bayalt well beaten together, by which, by Gods bleing, many, and I among others, have been freed from imple Tertians, and either double Tertians or Quotidians.

The Argument of the Poroity of Animals, drawn from thoe things that get in through their skins, without breaking or wounding them, may be much trengthned, if it can be made appear, that thoe Phyitians do not deceive us, who acribe enible Operations and Vertues, to things externally applyed, in o looe a way, that they do not o much as tick to the Skin, or perhaps immediately touch it; uch as ome call Periapta and Appena; divers of which are bet known among us, by the name of Amulets; uch as are the Quills containing Quick-ilver or Arenick, that ome hang about their necks, and
wear under their Shirts, againt the Plague and other Contagious Dieaes; and the Bloodtones that others wear againt Haemorrhages; and the tone which the Women ue in the Eat-Indies, for a quite contrary effect, in Obtructione Menium. That many of thee external Medicines, anwer not the promies of thoe that extol them, having ome of them no enible operation at all, and others no coniderable one, experience has aured judicious obervers; but that ome of them, epecially on ome Patients, may have coniderable, not to ay admirable, operations, I confes my elf by other motives, as well as Authority, to be perwaded. Having been one ummer frequently ubject to bleed at the Noe, and reduced to imploy everal remedies to check that ditemper; that which I found the mot effectual to tanch the blood, was ome mos of a dead mans Scull (ent for a preent out of Ireland where 'tis far les rare than in mot other Countrys) though it did but
touch my skin till the herb was a little warm'd by it. And though I remember not that I have known any great matter done to top Haemorrhagies by the bare outward application of other Blood-tones; yet of one that look'd almot like an Agate, I admired the effects, epecially upon a young and extraordinarily Sanguin peron. To which I hall add a memorable thing,If one would ee this paage at large he may find it at the end of the Eay. communicated to the experienced Zwelfer by the chief Phyitian of the States of Moravia. For this learned man whom he extols for a great Phyician and Philoopher; aures him, that having prepared ome Trochichs of Toads according to Helmonts way, (which I remember I alo was olicitous to prepare, but had not occaion to make tryal of their vertue,) he not only found, that being worn as Amulets they preerved him and all his Dometicks, and Friends, from the Plague (though he daily viited the infected) but that having caued thee
Trochichs to be put upon the Plague ores of everal perons, none of them died, but the venom of the petilential Carbuncles was thereby o weakened that the ulcers were afterward eaily cured by vulgar remedies.

And now, as to the difficulty, which I acknowledge not to be mall, to conceive how Bodies actually cold can emit Effluvia, capable of penetrating (without moitening it) a Membrane of o cloe a Contexture as a mans Skin; I uppoe it will be much leened in the objectors opinion, by what he will meet with hereafter about the Pores of Bodies, and the Figures of Corpucles. For uppoing thee to be congruous, it will not eem incredible, that the Effluvia of Amulets hould in tract of time get paage through the Pores of the Skin of a Living Body. And to make this the more probable, I will give an Intance in the Skin of a dead Animal. And, becaue this requires a Liquor I much employ in thee trials about Porology, though I have many years ince in
another Tract taught how to make it for another purpoe; yet I hall here repeat, that 'tis made by exactly mingling Flower of Brimtone, powdered Sal Armoniac and good Quicklime in equal quantities, ave that, if the Quicklime be not very dry and good, a fourth or fifth part mut be uperadded, for thee being nimbly mixed, and ditilled by degrees of Fire in a Retort, till the Sand be at length brought to be almot red hot, there will come over a moaking Spirit, which mut be kept very carefully topt, and which for ditinctions ake, I alo ue to call, The Permeating Mentruum or Liquor, and its expirations the Penetrant, or Permeating Fumes.

And now you will eaily undertand the experiment I was about to mention, which was this; We took a very clean piece of polih'd Copper, in want of which one of ilver will erve the turn, and having lapt it up in a piece of either Lambs or heeps Leather, o that it was every way
incloed, we then held it over the Orifice of the Vial that contained the Spirit, at a pretty ditance from the Liquor, whoe fumes nevertheles did quickly, (perhaps in a minute of an hour or les) pervade the Pores of the Leather, and operate upon the included metal as appeared by the deep and lating tincture it had given to the lower urface of it, though the interpoed Leather it elf was not deprived of its whitenes, nor at all enibly dicoloured; however it melt of the Sulplureous teams that had invaded it. And, if I miremember not, the ame Experiment ucceeded, though omewhat more lowly, when a double Leather was interpoed between the fumes and a new piece of Copper coin. This will be thought the les trange, when I hall come to ome other Intances of the Penetrancy of thee Spirits. In the mean while I leave it to be conidered, whether this may not ugget ome conjecture at that trange Phoenomenon, which is recorded by Authors of good repute,
That ometimes in great Thunders the Lightening, among other operations, has been found to have manifetly dicoloured mens money, without burning the Pures or Pockets wherein it lay. For in our experiment, the teams that in a trice pervaded the Leather, the mot uual matter whereof Pures are made, were ulphureous, as the mell argues, that thoe which accompany the Fulmen are wont to be; and whereas thee, when they invade Bodies, are uually very hot, ours operated when the Liquor that emitted them was actually cold. And if it be aid, that ometimes their money has been found dicolored in their Pockets, who were not truck, by the Fulmen, but had it only pas near them, it may be objected, that tho the intire Body, whether fluid or olid, if there be any of this latter kind that is in Latine called Fulmen (for our Englih word, Thunderbolt eems not o applicable to a fluid) did not touch them, yet it might catter teams enough round about it, to caue
the Phoenomenon. For confirmation of which I hall take notice, that a coniderable Peron of my acquaintance, having had the Curioity to acend a burning mountain in America, till the ulphureous teams grew too offenive to him, he told me that, among other operations he oberved them to have upon him, one was, that he found the money he had about him turned of a black and dirty colour, uch as I have oberved our ulphureous teams often give both to Copper, and to Silver Coins. But whether or no our Spirits will jutify the conjecture, they invited me to mention, at leat their o eaily pervading the Skin of a dead Animal may make it probable, that the Skin of a Living man may be eaily penetrated by external teams whoe approach the Eye does not perceive, and whoe operations, though not inconiderable, may therefore be unupected. I leave to Phyitians to conider, what ue may be made of this obervation, in reference to the propagation of contagious Dieaes, by the contact of
infected Air, ditinct from the Repiration of it, and by the penetration of the teams, that iuing from divers Bodies invade the Skin, and may perhaps be capable of operations, either hurtful or friendly, that are not uually upected to proceed from uch caues, and are therefore miacribed to others. And on this occaion it will not be impertinent to add, that by hanging up heeps Leather or Lambs Leather in the free Air, the vapors of it would o ininuate themelves into the Pores in wet weather, that a moderate degree of moiture in the Air would add to it a not inconiderable weight, of which dry weather, whether hot or cold, would deprive it.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
I Mut not in this place omit ome Intances, very proper to manifet the Penetrablenes of Membranes to Fumes themelves, if they be ubtile
enough for their Pores, or correpondent enough to them.

Among the obervations publihed by Phyicians I have met with ome by which it appears that Cantharides may have great Effects upon the internal Parts of the Body, though they do not o much as touch the Skin, but are placed at ome ditance from it,Schenkii Obervationum Lib. 7. Ob. 37. o that their Effluvia mut be tranmitted through other Bodies before they can penetrate that. The learned Michael Pachalius mentions a Chyrurgion, who was twice brought to void much Blood with his Urine, by ome Spanih Flies that he carryed about in a Pure or Bag. And another Doctor of note relates of another peron that came to complain to him, that he pied Blood, having carryed about with him Cantharides, though in his Pocket, and adds, that a like Cae was recounted to him by Helidaeus, whom he calls an eminent Bolognian Phyician.

We ee, that in Linnen Cloth, the
finer and more lender the threads are the cloer and les Porous, coeteris paribus, the Linnen is: By analogy to which one may eteem the thin film that lines the hell of an Egg, to be of an exceeding cloe Contexture; and yet that even this film is not impervious to ome Fumes, I have found by the following Tryal.

To make this, we lowly and warily pick'd off a ufficient part of the Shell of a Hens Egg, from the Skin that lay jut beneath it, and is wont to tick o cloe to it, that their eparation, without injuring the Membrane, is not eay. In this Skin, being wip'd, we wrapt up a flat piece of Copper, whoe urface was made bright, that the change of Colour might be the better een; and having kept this covered bit of Plate, over the Fumes of our moaking Liquor lately mentioned for a minute or two by our ghes we unfolded the Skin, and found, as we expected, that the lower urface of the Copper which was it that had been held over the
Fumes, was turned of a very dark colour, which manifeted that even o fine and cloely contexed a Membrane was not only, as we have formerly hewn, penetrable by Liquors, but readily pervious to our ulphureous exhalations, tho thee were probably but faintly emitted, ince the Liquor they came from was then actually cold. But in making the Tryal it is fit to hold (as we did in that newly recited) the Membrane againt the light, to ee if it be intire, and have ecaped all thoe little lacerations that are hardly avoidable in evering it from the Shell it ticks o cloe to. If this caution be neglected, 'tis eay to be impoed on, by overlooking ome little holes, that are not eaily dicerned when one looks down upon the Skin, and yet may be ufficient to make the Experiment deceitful. But, thô when 'tis well made, it is a notable confirmation of the Doctrine endeavoured to be etablihed in this Paper, yet I hall now ubjoyn a more coniderable
Intance to the ame purpoe.

The Porounes of the Internal Membranes of the Body, will be more eaily granted, if it be conidered that either the Liquors, or the moit Exhalations, whoe Action is promoted by the Natural Heat of the Parts, keeps them contantly wet or moit, and thereby renders them more lax, and more penetrable by ubtle Spirits or other Corpucles. In favour of this Reflection I made the following Experiment. We took a piece of a dryed Urinary Bladder, which was judged to have been a Calfs; and having lapt it about a new piece of Silver Coin, o that the Bladder was ingle where it covered the lower ide of the Piece, we kept it for divers Minutes, by gues, over the Spirituous Fumes of our often mentioned Permeating Liquor, but could not perceive that the Coin was thereby at all affected or ternihed. Whence we concluded that the Pores of the dry Bladder were too cloe and narrow to give paage to the Expirations of
the Mentruum. But preuming that moiture would ome what relax them with another piece of the ame Bladder, made limber by being a little wetted in common Water, we lapt up another like peace of new Coin, as we had done the former, and kept it at the ame ditance as before, from the Liquor, but not for o long a time. For after about two Minutes, by gues, we remov'd and took out the Piece, and, as we expected, found much of its lower urface (that regarded the Liquor) deeply dicoloured. Which Experiment will not only jutify what I lately aid, of the greater Laxity of moit than of dry Membranes, but will be thought no mean confirmation of what is in this Eay delivered about the Poroity of Membranes, ince the Urinary Bladder does, as Anatomits well know, conit of more than one Membrane, though they tick o cloe together, as to appear but one to the Eye. And this Bladder was peedily penetrated by
the Fumes that our Liquor emitted in exceeding Cold and Froty weather, though the Bladder it elf was not in the warm Body of the live Animal, but had been o long kept dryed and cold, that probably the Moiture it introduced in carce one minute of an Hour, could not retore it to the Laxity it had, whilt it was a part of the living Calf.

One of the notablet Intances I ever met with, of the Poroity of the Internal Membranes of the Humane Body, was afforded me by that Britih Nobleman, of whom our famous Harvey tells a memorable, not to ay matchles, tory. This Gentleman, having in his youth, by an accident which that Doctor relates, had a great and lating Perforation made in his Thorax, at which the motion of his Heart could be directly perceiv'd did not only out live the accident, but grew a trong, and omewhat corpulent man; and o robut, as well as Gallant, that he afterwards was a Souldier, and had
the honour to command a Body of an Army for the King. This Earl of Mount-Alexander (for that was his lat Title having marryed one of my nearet kinwomen, and having been told that I was very deirous to ee, what I had heard uch trange things of, very obligingly came, at a fit time, to give me that atisfaction. In order to which he removed that which covered the wide Orifice of his Hurt, and gave me the opportunity of looking into his Thorax, and of dicerning there the motions of the Cone, as they call it, or Mucro of the Heart. But thee things I mention but upon the by, and becaue of the trangenes of the fact; the thing I principally intended relates to my preent argument. Having then made everal inquiries fit for my purpoe, his Lordhip told me, that when he did, as he was wont to do from time to time, (though not every day) inject with a Syringe ome actually warm medicated Liquor into his Thorax, to cleane and cherih the
Parts, he hould quickly and plainly find in his Mouth the tat and mell of the Drugs, wherewith the Liquor had been impregnated. And I further learned, that, whereas he contantly wore upon the uncloed part of his Chet, a Silken Quilt, tuffed with Aromatick and odoriferous Powders, to defend the neighbouring Parts and keep them warm; when he came, as he ued to do after ome weeks, to imploy a new Quilt, the fragrant Effluvia of it would mingle with his breath in expiration, and very enibly perfume it, not, as I declared I upected, upon the core of the pleaing Exhalations that might get up between his Clothes and his Body, but that got into the Organs of Repiration, and came out with his Breath at his Mouth, as was confirmed to me by a grave & judicious Stateman, that happened to be then preent, and knew this General very well. Other circumtances I might add, but that I dare not trut my memory for them, and unhappily lot the Paper,
wherein the oddnes of the things invited me to et them down, for fear of forgetting them.

That part of this Narrative which relates to Injections may be much confirm'd by what is delivered by Galen himelf, who ays that Mulum or Honeyed Water, being injected at the Orifice of Wounds penetrating into the cavity of the Thorax, has been oberved to be in part received into the Lungs, and dicharged out of the Apera Arteria by coughing. And this he mentions as a known thing, imploying it as a Medium whereby to prove another.

The mention that has been made of the Poroity of Membranes, brings into my mind what I once oberved at the Diection, made by ome Phyicians, and Anatomits, of a luty Souldier, that was hanged for I know not what crime. This man, though otherwie young and ound, was oberved to have been long moleted with what they call a hort, dry Cough, which made us expect to find omething
much amis in his Lungs. But meeting with nothing there, we were at a los for the caue of this Cough, till coming to conider the internal part of the Chet, we perceived omething on one of the ides, by tracing of which we dicovered, that between the Pleura and the ubtance of the intercotal mucles, there was lodged a certain matter, of the breadth of a Silver Crown piece, or thereabouts, of a roundih figure, and of the conitence and almot colour of new, oft Cheee, which odd tuff was concluded to have been the remains of ome ill cured Pleuriy, and to have tranmitted through the Pores of the Pleura, though that be a very cloe Membrane, ome noxious Effluvia, which ever and anon irritated the Lungs into an irregular and troubleom motion, and o produced the Cough the Malefactor had been moleted with.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p: I Am well aware that 'tis far les difficult, to prove the permeablenes of ingle Membranes, than that of uch a Part of the Body, as eems to be an aggregate of everal parts, which in regard of their cloe adheion, are looked upon but as one part, to which, on that account, men commonly give a ditinct name. But yet there are ome Phaenomena that eem to argue, that even uch compounded or reulting parts if I may o call them, are not detitute of Pores, which whether they be not ome of them the Orifices of exceeding lender and therefore unoberved Capillary Veels, I mut not now tay to enquire.

When the cavity of the Abdomen in thoe Hydropical Perons that are troubled with an Acites, is filled with Water, or rather with a Liquor that I have found to be much more vicous, it jutly appears trange, that by an
Hydragogue, or ome appropriated purging medicine, great quantities of this gros Liquor hould in a hort time be carryed off by Siege, and perhaps alo by Urine, though to get into the cavity of the Guts, or that of either of the Kidneys, it eems neceary that it Permeate the Tunicles, and other component parts, of the Vicera it gets into.

I know not whether I may on this occaion take notice of what Phyicians oberve to occur now and then in Empyema's that follow ill conditioned Pleuriies. For it has everal times been oberved, that upon the burting of uch impothumes into the cavity of the Chet, the Purulent matter hath been voided by Siege and Urine. I heitate, as I was aying, whether I hould alledge this Phaenomenon, as a proof of what I now contend for, till it be determined whether this Metatais be made by tranudation properly o called, or by the ingres of the Pus into the imperfectly cloed Orifices of the Veels of the Lungs;
where being once admitted and mingled with the Blood they may with this circulating Liquor arrive at the Kidneys, or any other Parts fitted to make a ecretion of this Heterogeneous matter.

But whatever be the Reaon or manner of it, we find that the Lungs do ometimes odly convey things to ditant parts of the Body. And if I may here mention a thing, cui honos praefationis et, I hall add that I have everal times oberv'd in my elf, that when I had been an actor or an aitant in the Diection of a living Dog, epecially if his Blood or Body were rankly Scented, I hould divers hours after plainly find that odour in the excrements I voided by Siege.

A famous Chirurgeon and Anatomit relates, that one who was very ill of a dropy, judged to arie from a Scirrhus of the Spleen, coming to ask his counel and aitance, though he judged the patients cae deperate, yet to content him, he ordered him to dip a very large Sponge in good Quicklime-Water,
and having queezed out the uperfluous Liquor, to bind it upon the region of the Spleen, only hifting it from time to time. He adds, that after ome months he was much urprized to receive a viit from this Patient, with olemn thanks for his recovery; the outward Medicine having, it eems, reolved the Scirrhus and concurred with nature to evacuate the hydropical humour. For the reolution of which hard tumour it eems neceary, that the anative Corpucles of the external remedy hould at length penetrate, not only the Epidermis, and the true Cutis, but the Mucles themelves of the Abdomen, and ome other interpoed parts.

Thee intances may be trengthen'd by an eminent obervation of Galen, who takes notice that Bones being ometimes broken, without piercing the Skin that covers the part they belong to, when the Callus is making, and the broken parts of the Bone begin to be conglutinated together, a Portion
of that Blood which had flowed to the part affected is carryed to the Skin and permeats that, o as to wet and foul the Dreings or Bandages that are kept upon the limb affected by the Fracture.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p: BOnes, Horns, and parts of the like Subtance, being thoe that are granted to be the mot olid of the Bodies of Animals, I come in the lat place to hew by particular Experiments that thee alo have their Pores. I ay, by particular Experiments, becaue in a general way, their Poroity has been already proved, by the ame Arguments, from their original Texture, Nutrition, Augmentation, &c. That have been employed to manifet the Porounes of Animal ubtances in general.

That the Nails of men, as well as their Skins, are Porous, may be gathered from their being eaily and
permanently tinged with divers metalline olutions, and particularly with thoe of ilver in Aquafortis, and Gold in Aqua Regia; the former of which olutions though cold, will but too eaily tinge the Skin and Nails it chances to touch, and makes ome little tay upon, with a dark and blackih colour; which I found not that I could wah out with water, or, even with a far more penetrating and abterive liquor. The like durablenes I found in the Purple pots, that I ometimes purpoely made on my Nails, by letting ome little drops of the olution of Gold in Aqua Regia dry upon them, which I now and then did, to oberve the way of the Nails growth. For if the tain were made near the root of the nail, it would be till, though very lowly, thrut on by the new matter, till after ome weeks it arrived to the further end of the Nail, and was fit to be pared off with it. But this only upon the by. 'Tis more to our purpoe to take notice, that, though the Mentruums imployed in the recited
Experiments be of themelves very acid and corroive, yet they are o changed by the metals they have diolved, that they are Acid no more, the olution of Silver being rather extreamly bitter, and that of Gold of a kind of Stiptic tat, almot like that which loes, growing in the hedges, are wont to be of.

Ivory is a thing too well known to need to be decribed. And, ince 'tis generally lookt upon (for I have had no opportunity to compare it with the Bones) as the olidet part of the vatet of Teretrial Animals, Experiments proving its poroity, will be trong preumptions for that of the hardet parts of other Animals. And the Porounes of Ivory may be argued from the everal ways of dying it with permanent colours. For in thee colorations the Tinctures that make them, mut penetrate into, and be lodged in the Subtance of the Ivory, epecially when the Subtance remains mooth and glay, as I have divers times made it do, when I employed
fit Mentruums and Metalline Pigments. The olution I formerly mentioned of Silver in Aqua fortis, being laid upon Ivory, will oon give it a dark and blackih tain, which is not, that I have found, to be wahed off. I remember alo that I many years ince taught ome ingenious artificers, to adorn Ivory with a fine purple colour, by moitening it with, and uffering leiurely to dry on it, a olution of Gold made in Aqua Regia. And if occaion required, allayed with water, nor needs either of thee olutions be applyed hot, any more than the Ivory needs to be heated. Both which circumtances favour the Porounes of the olid Body.

Copper diolved in Aqua fortis tains Ivory with a blewih colour, as I have ometimes een in the hafts of knifes, about whoe coloration nevertheles another way is alo employed. But I remember that without making ue of any Acid or Corroive Mentruum, I have even in the cold tained Ivory, with a fine and permanent
blew, like a Turquois, by uffering to dry upon it as deep a olution as I could make of Crude Copper, in an urinous Spirit, as that of Sal Armoniack.

But now to return to Bones, their growth in all their dimenions, does, as I lately noted, argue their Poroity and the marrow that is found in the great hollow Bones, whether it nourih them or no, mut it elf be upplyed by ome alimental juice, that oaks or otherways penetrates, into the cavities that contain it.

Nor does it eem at all improbable, that Blood it elf may through mall Veels be conveyed into the very ubtance of the Bone, o as that the Veels reach at leat a little way in it, though perhaps the Liquor they carry may afterwards by Imbibition be brought to the more internal parts of the Bone. For not to urge that we manifetly ee, that on each ide of the lower Jaw, Nature has been careful to perforate the Bones and make a Channel in the ubtance of it; which Channel
receives not only a larger Nerve but a Vein, & Artery to bring in & carry back Blood for the nourihment of the Teeth, by ditinct Sprigs ent from the great branch to the particular Teeth. Not to urge this, I ay, (which I mention but to hew that the opinion lately propoed is agreeable to a known practice of Nature) I have been aured by eminent Anatomits, whom I purpoely conulted, that they have oberved Blood-veels to enter a great way into the ubtance of the larger Bones. And one of them affirmed, that he had traced a Veel even to the great Cavity of the Bone. Which I the les crupled to admit, becaue it has been oberved, that in younger Animals the Cavity is in great part furnihed with Blood as well as Marrow, and in thoe larger Pores, whereof many are found in the more Spongy Subtance of divers Bones, Blood has been oberved to have been lodged, as alo in the pongy part of the Skull, that lies between the two Tables, as I have been aured by Skilful Eyewitnees.

The blacknes alo, that Bones acquire when put into a competent heat, and a peculiar kind of fatnes which they may by heat be made to afford, hew that they harbour, even in their internal parts, tore of Unctuous Particles, eparable from the olid ubtance, (which till retains its hape and continues olid) in whoe Pores they may thereby be argued to have been lodged. The Lightnes of Bones, even when their Cavity is acceible to (Air and) Water, is alo a great ign of their Poroity. And o is their being corroded by tinging liquors, if they be penetrative and well applyed. I know not whether I hould add on this occaion, that having taken calcined and pulverized Bones, uch as we ue to make our Cupels of, and, after having given them a good heat, kept them for ome time in the Air, but in a well covered place; I found the imbibed moiture of the Air to have manifetly increaed their weight; and that I alo oberved in a curious Skeleton,
where the Bones were kept together by wires, intead of other Ligaments, that though I kept it in a well covered place, not far from a Kitchin Fire, yet in very moit weather the Bones eemed to well, ince thoe joynts that were eay to be bent, in dry weather, and that after everal manners, would grow tiff and refractory, and indipoed to be put into uch motions, when the weather was coniderably wet. Thee particulars (as I was aying) I am omewhat doubtful whether I hould here inert, becaue one may upect the Phaenomena may proceed rather from omewhat ele, than the imbibed moiture of the Air; and yet I would not omitt to mention thee obervations, becaue I do not yet ee any caue to which they may more probably (or indeed o probably) be aigned.

And on this occaion I hall ubjoyn ome obervations made on large and olid Ox Bones, which in one of my Note Books I find thus regitred. Nov. 15. We weighed two [entire or unbroken]
Marrow Bones, and found the one to weigh xxix + s, and the other xxiv + iv + 30 gr. Nov. 24. The former weighed xxix + vi, and the latter xxv + i + 30 gr. Decemb. 28. the former weighed xxix + iij. 55 gr. and the latter xxiv + vii. + 39 gr. June 7th of the following year, the former weigh'd xxix + ii. And the latter xxiv + vii. By which obervations purpoely made at differing times of the year, and in very good cales, it eems that Bones do plentifully enough imbibe the Exhalations of the Air, and emit them again, together with ome of their own, according as the ambient happens to be dipoed. And thee alterations argue the Bones to abound with Pores, ince the external teams mut have Pores to receive them, and the Effluvia mut upon their reces leave Pores behind them.

I confes that to think (as with ome Anatomits I lately eemed to do) that Bones themelves admit into their ubtance, Veels capable of
conveying a nutritive Liquor, we mut uppoe thoe Veels extreamly lender. But that 'tis not only poible but omewhat credible, there may be uch, I am induced to think, by what is known to happen in that dieae, which from the Country it mot infets is called the Plica Polonica. For, tho one would think that the hairs of men are much too lender, to have cavities in them capable of viible Liquors; and though I have found it very difficult, even with a good Microcope, to perceive any cavities in the hair of a man tranverly cut; yet not only ome other writers of good note, but the Judicious Sennertus himelf deliver, that in this dieae (of which he particularly treats) it has been oberved, that if the Patients caue their intangled hair to be cut, as they ometimes do, by reaon of its natines or unightlines, they are not only thereby endangered, but ometimes the ingle hairs will actually bleed, where the ends have been cut off; o that o thick a Liquor as Blood may be conveyed
through Veels, that can at mot be but in a proper ene Capillary and mut be far les than hairs, if their Perforations be like thoe by which many Plants have their nourihment conveyed to them, or uch as are obvious in divers Canes, which being cut quite through transverly, dicover a multitude of ditinct Pores, that by ome Experiments one may be induced to gues, reach all along, and make the Cane like a Cylindrical Bundle of Minute Pipes; or rather a multitude of mall cavities, that perforate from end to end the Parenchyma, or Subtance analogous to it, that gives them tability. And for the preent this ort of Veels eem to me, the more likely to be thoe that convey the Blood to the extream Parts of the Hair, becaue even in Hore hairs, which yet are nourihed and grow, I am not yet ure, that I have dicovered with my Microcopes any cavity, and therefore upect there may be divers imperceptible ones, for the Hair is nourihed and grows, which it is not like
it hould do if the Body were olid; and if there were but a ingle cavity in it, as in the lower part of a Quill, 'tis like the Microcope I ued would have dicovered it, ince with one much inferiour I could eaily ee, that everal little hort Hairs, that grow upon the Animal that yields Musk, had each of them a cavity in it like that of the lower part of a Quill.

To the things that have already been aid about the Poroity of Bones, I hall now add an obervation of a very learned Phyician, that is very remarkable to our preent purpoe, becaue it argues, that even Bodies not aline, nor actually moit, may from without get into the Pores and Cavities of Humane Bones. Divers Phyicians have complain'd of the michiefs done to the Bones by Mercury, employ'd to alivate in Venereal Dieaes. Whereof I remember I have read a very notable Intance, in a learned Book (which I have not now by me) of an eminent Roman Profeor of Phyick, who had the opportunity
of making everal curious obervations in the famous Hopital of the Incurabili at Rome; and is therefore the more to be credited; where he relates, that in the Cavity of at leat one Pocky-mans Bones, there was found real Quick-Silver that had penetrated thither. And this brings into my mind a memorable obervation of an ancient and experienced Phyician, who being famous for the cure of Venereal Dieaes, was asked by me, what Intances he had found of the Penetration of Quick-Silver, either outwardly or inwardly adminitred, into the Bones of men? To this he anwered, that he could not ay he had himelf taken notice of any Quick-Silver, in the Cavities of greater Bones, but that ome other Practitioners had told him, that they had met with uch Intances, as I enquired after. But for himelf, he only remembred that a Patient, who had been terribly fluxed with mercurial Inunctions, coming afterwards to have one of the Grinders of his lower Jaw pulled out,
becaue of the raging pain it had long put him to; my Relater had the curioity to view narrowly this great Tooth, and found, to his wonder, a little drop of true Mercury in that lender Cavity of the Root, that admits the mall Veels which convey nourihment and ene to the Tooth, in more than one of whoe three Roots he affirmed to me that he found true, though but exceeding little, Quick-Silver. But a full Tetimony to my preent purpoe is afforded me by the experienced Phyician Eutachius Rudius, who relates,Eutach. Rudius (apud Sennertum) lib. 5. de morbis acutis cap. 15. that he aw himelf, and that others alo oberved, ome Bodies diected, of thoe that had been anointed for the Venereal Pox, in the Cavities of whoe Bones no mall quantity of Quick Silver was got together, (which yet (to add that upon the by) he ays, did not hinder ome of them from living many years, urviving thoe Inunctions.)

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
div.p:
I Am not ignorant that, among the Particulars laid together in the foregoing Eay, there are ome that are not abolutely neceary, to prove the Porounes of the Bodies of Animals. But I thought it not impertinent to mention them, becaue I hoped that they, in conjunction with the ret, may be of ome ue to Naturalits, in giving an account of everal things that pas in a Humane Body, whether ound or ick, epecially if it be of a Topical dieae, and may remove, or much leen that great Prejudice, that makes many (and ome of them otherwie learned) Phyicians depie the ue of all Amulets, Pericarpia, and other external Medicines in Ditempers of the Inward parts, upon a confident, but not well grounded uppoition, that thee Remedies immediately touching but the outide of the Skin, cannot exercie any coniderable operations
upon the internal parts of the Body.

But though I have thus acknowledged ome Paages of the foregoing Eay to be upernumerary, yet I mut not dimis it without intimating that I might from one Topick more have fetched a probable, though not a demontrative argument, in favour of the Porounes of Animals. For this may be very probably argued from hence, that even Inanimate, Solid and Ponderous Bodies, that in all likelyhood mut be of a far cloer Texture than the living Bodies of Animals (whoe various Functions require a greater number and diverity of Pores in their differing Organs) are not devoid of Pores, and have ome of them very numerous ones, as will be ufficiently made out in the following Eay, to which I hall therefore haten.
