div.head: An Eay of the POROUSNESS OF SOLID BODIES.
CHAP. I
div.p:
AS 'twill with far les difficulty be allowed, that Animals and Vegetables, and uch Bodies, as have belonged to either, abound with Pores, than that Inanimate, Solid, and even Ponderous Bodies are not detitute of them: So 'tis far les difficult to make out the former than the latter of thee Propoitions.
And therefore, Pyrophilus, I hope you will not expect that I hould give you as many proofs of the one, as I have of the other; however I depair not, that thoe I hall preent you, will appear ufficient for my purpoe, though they be not numerous enough to make me careful to marhal them in any exact order.

Of the reaons that induce me to think that even Solid Bodies are not detitute of Pores, there are ome that have a greater Affinity with thoe arguments that the Schools are wont to call à priori, becaue they require more unobvious Ratiocinations upon Phyical Principles, and others which reemble, and indeed are, uch proofs as are uually named à poteriori, being uggeted by the Phaenomena afforded us by experience, without the help of any difficult Ratiocinations.

Of the Firt ort of Reaons I hall propoe to you three; and begin with that, which may be drawn from the Origine and Formation of divers hard
Bodies.See the Tract of the Origine and Vertues of Gems, and the Notes about the Mechanical production of Hardnes. For I have elewhere endeavour •• and I hope not unu •
cesfully, to hew, both that divers tones, and even Gems themelves, and that everal Metalline and other Mineral Bodies, were once either viible Liquors or at leat very oft ubtances. And I have elewhere proved, that both thee kinds of Bodies do conit of, (which is the cae of Liquors) or abound in (which is the cae of oft and moit Bodies) minute particles of determinate Sizes and Shapes; from whence I think one may very probably conclude, that uch Gems and other Mineral Bodies, notwithtanding any hardnes they afterwards come to acquire, are not detitute of Pores, ince 'tis no way likely, that Corpucles of various and very irregular Figures, uch as thoe of mot Liquors of the terretrial Globe are wont to be, can be o brought together, epecially by chance, cold, or any other uch agents, as not to intercept little Intervals or Pores between them.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p:
ANother thing which makes me think the Poroity of the mot part even of Solid Bodies to be great, is the conideration of the great diparity, that may be found in the pecifick Gravities of uch Bodies, as the Eye does not perceive to be Porous. For, though Water be a Body of that kind, and though its parts be o cloe packt together, that the attempts of Ingenious men, to make a manifet compreion of that Liquor by outward violence, have not hitherto proved uccesful, yet we find, that tones, Clays, metals, and even ome Woods and a multitude of other kinds of Solids, will readily ink in Water, and by conequence are pecifically heavyer than it; which greater gravity eems not any way explicable, without uppoing, or at leat o well as by uppoing, that the Corpucles whereof
uch inking Bodies conit, do either lye cloer together, or are eparately more olid, than thoe of Water; which Liquor mut conequently be Porous, though neither the Eye, nor the great force that has been everal ways employed to compres it, can dicover any Pores in it. Upon the ame ground I further conclude, that olid Stones themelves, as Marble, Flints, &c. Are not free from Poroity. For whereas, as far as everal Tryals purpoely made can inform me, I have found, that uch of thee as have nothing metalline in them do eldom or never reach to treble the weight of an equal bulk of Water, they will, upon the former grounds, appear to be coniderably Porous; ince the lightet metals, which are Tin and Iron, are above twice heavier in pecie, that is, the bulks being equal, than Marble, Flints, Chrytal, &c. And by the ame reaon I alo infer the great Poroity, even of the Solid Body of Iron, which is as well heavier, as very much harder, than Tinn. For though
Copper be a good deal more ponderous than Iron, or Steel, yet I have divers times found fine Gold, to be more than twice as heavy in pecie as Copper, ince, whereas this Metal, whether it be European, or brought from Japan (for of that alo I made Tryal) is about nine times as heavy as o much Water; I found refined Gold to be about nineteen times as heavy as Water equal to it in bulk. By which it eems highly probable, that o olid and heavy a Body, as Iron or Steel it elf, may be o porous, that Metalline matter equal to it in weight may naturally be contained in much les than half the Dimenions that Metal poees. And that Gold it elf, which is the mot comPact and olid Body we know of, is not detitute of Pores, may appear by the Diolution of it in Quick-Silver, of which I hall peak a little below. And if any hould pretend, that hardnes may be a greater argument of the Compactnes of a Body, and its immunity from Pores, than its pecifick weight can be; I
hall add, that though I have found that Emery, which is the Body employed to cut teel and Load-tones and Crytal, and the mot of Gems, being indeed much harder than Marble or Flints, be far heavier than thrice its bulk of Water; yet that ponderounes proceeds, as I ele where intimate, from the mixture of a metalline Subtance, which I have eparatted from it. And Diamonds, though much harder Bodies than Emery, and indeed the hardet we know of in nature, are o far from being, as ome of late have written, the mot ponderous of Bodies, that having examined them hydrotatically, by a way elewhere mentioned, I found them not much heavier than either Crytal, or fine Glas, and not half o heavy as the lightet Metals.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: THe next thing, from which the Porounes of Solid Bodies, and even thoe that belong to the Mineral Kingdom (as the Chymits peak) may be deduced, is the ame with the firt of thoe from which we formerly argued the Poroity of Subtances belonging to the Animal Kingdom, namely, the very frame & contitution of uch Bodies. For the olidet Bodies themelves, reulting from the Convention or Coalition of a great number of Particles of everal bignees and hapes, we cannot reaonably uppoe, (epecially in thoe concretes wherein they are not ranged by a eminal Principle) that they hould be contexed o, as to touch one another exactly every where and therefore they mut of neceity leave ome little Intervals and Pores between them.

This reaon will, I hope, appear clear enough of it elf, to him that hall attentively conider it, epecially if he know, that it has been Geometrically demontrated, that there are but very few figures that will, (as they peak) implere patium, that is, which being adjuted to one another will o exactly touch, that there is not the leat unfilled pace within the circumference or circuit, if the figures be plain, or within the ambient Superficies, if they be olid; o that, conidering the vat variety of other Figures, which made Epicurus and other Atomits pronounce it incomprehenible, 'tis very obvious to conceive, that Corpucles of uch differing hapes being put together, will leave multitudes of little Pores intercepted, between thoe parts that do not every where touch one another. And even the Mathematical Figures lately poken of, may be aid to fill pace rather in a Geometrical than a Phyical ene. For, if uch Portions of matter as are required to contitute, for intance, a Cube,
were actually put together, they would not exactly fill the pace comprehended within the ambient urface of the Body they compoe, becaue the component Bodies, being Phyical, conit of Corpucles of their own particular hapes, which we never find Mathematically exquiite. As if, for example, the Cube were of Marble, no Art could polih the ides of a component Body o, as that they hould be perfectly moothed ince (as, if I mitake not, the learned Gaendus well oberves) Emery, Pumice-tone, and even Puttee, or other Powders that are employed to polih them, do themelves conit of little hard angular Corpucles, that leave mall cratches, like o many little furrows, on their urfaces, which mut needs hinder the perfect contact of the whole urfaces of two contiguous Bodies, and conequently leave here and there Intervals or Pores, between thoe urfaces; to which I hall add that Marble it elf as 'tis Marble, abounds with internal Pores, as will ere long appear by
Experience, and as may be rationally conjectured from the Specifick Levity of it, in comparion of Gold and Lead.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: HAving dipatched the Arguments à priori, that may be imployed to hew the Porounes of Solid Bodies, 'twill be now eaonable to propoe ome Experiments and obervations, that may (as 'twere) à poteriori either evince or confirm the ame Doctrine.

Of thee Intances ome relate to Solid Bodies that are of les pecifick gravity ome to Foiles preumed to be devoid of Metalline parts, ome to Minerals that are thought to participate of a Metalline nature, ome to Metals themelves, and ome to Glas.

To begin with the firt ort of thee Intances; That Wood is Porous, there are many things that argue; ome of which are elewhere mentioned. But few would upect, that Quick-Silver which is o unapt to enter the Pores
of Bodies much les compact, hould permeate peices of Wood of a coniderable thicknes; and yet, that we have made it do by the following Experiment. We took a wooden Trunk, uch as is employed to hoot pellets at Birds, with trength enough to kill them, and having cloely topt one end of it, we poured in Quick Silver at the other, till it reached to a good height in the cylindrical Cavity of the Intrument, and then the lower parts of the Metalline Liquor, being aited by the weight of the Incumbent ones, (not to mention that of the Air) to pres into the Pores of the Wood, they iued out at them on all ides, in great numbers of minute drops, much after the manner of Quick-Silver trained through Leather, out of amalgams; which was a Phaenomenon not unpleaant to behold. But till I have opportunity to repeat this Experiment with differing circumtances, I hall not think it fit to lay much tres upon it, for want of knowing, what interet the great weight of the Quick Silver may have had in the event.

And this caution may perchance be applicable to the following Experiment, namely, that having, by the help of my Pneumatical Engine, withdrawn the Air from one ide of a round peice of board, the Air on the oppoite ide, not having its preure any longer reited by that which it ued to meet with from the withdrawn Air, preed o trongly againt the urface of the Wood expoed to it, as to make it elf way through the Pores of it, and get copiouly enough into the Cavity whence the other Air had been pumpt out; (the weight of the incumbent Atmophere doing on this occaion, what the weight of the Quick-Silver did on that lat recited:) Which was a urprizing pectacle to the by-tanders becaue the board that was thus permeated, was of trong Wood, and of coniderable thicknes.

I hould here ubjoin everal other Arguments of the Porounes of Wood, if I could diplay them without more words, than I am willing to allow them;
and I preume it may here uffice, if I let you ee by ome urprizing Effects that when Wood is reduced to that thinnes, that its cloenes or Poroity may conveniently be examined, it will eaily enough give paage, even unto viible, odorable, and tinging Corpucles though they invade it not in the form of a Liquor, but of dry Exhalations, o they be not incommenurate to its Pores. This I uppoe, you will not cruple to infer from the following Tryals, as they were long ince et down in one of my Note-Books.

1. The Fumes of our moaking Liquor [decribed in the foregoing Eay] tinged a Copper half penny, through a broad thin having of Dale, that did not, when held againt the window, dicover any perforation; tinged it, I ay, very deeply in about a quarter of a minute and omewhat les.

2. The ame Fumes tinged manifetly, but not o notably, the ame half penny firt cleaned through two uch havings of Dale, laid one upon
another in omwhat les than one minute.

3. And in about one minute the ame Fumes tinged the cleaned half penny, through three uch havings of Dale very viibly, but not o conpicuouly, as through the two forementioned. Thee Tryals were made without the help of heat to promote the operation of the Fumes.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: FRom the conideration of Woods let us now proceed to give ome Intances of the Porounes of Bodies made of cloe and compacted, and perhaps well baked Clays or other Earths.

That Earthen Veels, thô trong and well bak'd, are many of them porous enough may be argued not only from what has been lately recited, but from hence, that ome of them will uffer themelves to be
oakt through by Oyl. Others by olutions of Nitre, and ome other Salts. And there are very few of them, without excepting Haian Crucibles themelves, that will long keep Salt of Tartar, and uch like fixt Alcalies, in fuion without being penetrated by them. I have heard Ditillers complain, that when they have ditilled corroive materials, as Vitriol and Salt-Petre, with trong fires, in thoe Earthen Veels that are commonly made ue of in London (epecially by refiners) intead of Retorts though their necks be trait and long (upon which account they are called long-necks) a coniderable quantity of the finet Spirits make their ecape quite thorow the Veel; o that in the Retort and Receiver many ounces are found wanting, of the firt weight of the matter to be ditilled. And this ometimes, when the Vitriol has been previouly calcin'd, and a reaonable allowance has been made, for what may have ecaped thorow the Lute, that joined together the long Neck and Receiver.
And though I have oberved of our Bottles, made of the ame Earth with Juggs, that they are hard enough to trike Fire with a good Steel, yet a good Experimenter upon uch Veels of whom I made enquiry, has aured me that thee, as compact as they are, may, even without external heat, have their Pores pervaded by the finer parts of Spirituous Liquors.

To this purpoe I remember that meeting once with a Virtuoo, that was curious about the ways of making Sider as brisk and pirituous a Liquor as he could; I enquired of him, whether he was able to keep in the ubtil Spirit of this Skilfully fermented Liquor, in thoe earthen Bottles, that, by reaon of the olidity they acquire by the vehement coction of the Fire, are commonly called tone Bottles; to which he replyed. that he often found to his trouble, that the Liquor would permeate the compact Subtance of the Bottles: And when I objected that the Spirits might either ecape out at the Cork, which I have made everal Spirits
of divers kinds that would readily permeate; he replyed, that what he had aid appeared by the outide of the Bottles: To which when I further objected, that the ight of dew on the urface of the Bottles, would not convince me, without tating whether it were vinous, becaue I had divers times oberved, that brisk Liquors would produce a dew, on the outide of the Veels that contained them, not by any tranudation (for I have made Tryal of it in Glaes) but by condening the aqueous vapors, dipered through the neighbouring part of the Ambient Air: He replyed that, beides what his tat had informed him of the quality of this dew, he found that the included Liquor, though exactly topt, wated in not very many Months o coniderably, as ometimes to loe a ixth, or even a fifth part; & this ecape or percolation of the Liquor through the Subtance of the Veels, he affirmed himelf to have oberved, not only in one or two Bottles, but in very many and the like obervation for the
main was confirmed to me, upon his own experience, by an eminent Phyician, who, being a great Lover of brisk Sider, ued to bottle it up early and carefully.

Though good Haian Crucibles be very cloely compacted, as well as throughly baked Bodies, and upon that account are able to keep Silver and divers other Metals long in fuion, without letting them at all run out; yet having diolved Silver in Aqua fortis, I oberved that, though the Salts were by this operation o chang'd that this horn-like Silver did diolve neither in the Aqua fortis, nor in the Aqua Regia that I put it into; yet when I kept it a while in fuion, (which 'tis eaily brought to be) among quick Coals, it would without cracking or perforating the Crucible, oak into it, and permeate the Pores of it, in I know not how many places, as I convinced ome curious perons, by hewing them on the outide of the Veel, a multitude of minute globules of pure Silver, like o many little drops, that
were got thither, as it were, by tranudation.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p: FRom baked Earths, that are deigned in point of hardnes to emulate tones, we will proceed to give ome intances of the Porounes of Natural Stones themelves.

There goes a tradition, that in ome part of the Wet-Indies they have a Stone, of which they make large Veels, wherein they put Water to percolate, as it were, through a trainer. Of thee Veels I had one ent me for a preent, whereof being hereafter to give ome account in a more opportune place, I hall now only take notice that I found that Water would (thô lowly) oak through the Veel, thô it were coniderably thick.

If, as many of the Ancients, and
mot of the modern Corpucular Philoophers have conceived, the Tranparency and Opacity of Bodies proceeds from a Rectitude or Crookednes of Pores, which makes them fit or unfit to transmit the Light, that tends to pervade them in Phyically traight Lines: If this Hypotheis, I ay, be allowed, we may draw a very probable argument, that Stones may be Porous, from the Phaenomena of that odd Gem, that is bet known by the name of Oculus Mundi. For this mall tone (at leat that which I made my Obervations of) when 'tis dry, and is kept in the Air, is opacous, almot like a polihed piece of white Amber, and o it continues, as long as 'tis kept dry. But if you put it into fair water, it will in no long time, become by degrees quite Tranparent, and that which I made Tryal of looked then not unlike a piece of clear yellow Amber which by degrees does in the free Air loe its Tranparency and turn to be opacous as before. Now according to the above mentioned
Corpucular Hypotheis, the Pellucidnes which the Stone acquires in Water, may be accounted for, by aying, that the Liquor getting in at the crooked Pores of the Stone, does for the time rectify them, and make them pervious to the traight Beams of Light; as we ee that White Paper, being wetted with Water, or, which does far better, being made o imbide Oyl, has its Pores o changed and rectified, that the Water much leens its Opacity, and makes it almot Semidiaphanous and the Oyl, if it be fine and well oaked up, makes it Tranparent. But upon the reces or evaporation of the imbibed Particles of Water, the Pores of the little Stone becoming crooked again reflect the Rays of light they hould tranmit. Which explication will be the better allowed of, if my memory do not miinform me, when it tells me, that a learned Member of the Royal Society found the Oculus Mundi to weigh more in a nice ballance, when it was taken out of the Water and well wiped, than before
it was put in. This Stone, which very few of the writers about Gems take notice of, is o rare and difficult to be got, that I had not opportunity to make upon it all the Tryals I deired; and therefore, though the Subject be curious, I may, I hope, be excued, if I haten from it to another.

There is o much difference in many Qualities betwixt Stones and Metals, that 'tis very probable, that when the Corpucles of both come to be brought together into one Mas, they will not touch one another o cloe, as not to leave tore of little Intervals or Pores between them. And upon this ground I have been apt to think that divers very hard Stones, Diaphanous and Opacous, are not devoid of Poroity. For I have elewhere delivered a way by which I have obtained good tore of Metalline parts, both from American Granats, and from Emery; though this lat be o exceeding hard a Stone, that 'tis uually imployed by artificers to work upon
Iron and Steel, and to cut not only Rock Crytal, but divers Gems that are harder than either that or Steel.

Upon the ame ground one may probably infer the Poroity of many Artificial Gems made by Fuion; for to give thee the colour of Sapphirs, Topazes, Amethyts, &c. we are wont to add to the vitrifiable matter, either ome prepared metal, as calcined Copper, calx of Gold, &c. or ele ome Mineral as Zaffora and Manganeze (as the Glas-men call Magneia) that abounds in Metalline parts. Nay I remember, I have ometimes given the colour to the vitrified ubtance, by imploying natural Gems, as Granats; though to hew that the coloration which the mas received from thee, proceeded from the Metalline Corpucles, that lay hid in the tinging matter, the Colour produced was not that which was conpicuous in the Gem it elf, but one very different from it, and uch as the metal, which upon other accounts I uppoed the Gem to partake of, ought, according to the
Grounds I proceeded upon, to produce in the vitrifiable matter. And this very Experiment makes it alo highly probable, that even natural tranparent Gems, (divers of which are much harder than Marble, Iron & even Steel) are themelves Porous; ince, notwithtanding their Tranparency and eeming Homogeneity. They are made up of Ingredients of uch differing natures as are Stony and Metalline Corpucles.

From the ame Ground we may likewie deduce the Poroity of Marcaites; many of which I have oberved to be, not only hard enough, plentifully to trike fire by colliion with Steel, but more ponderous than even divers Oars, that were rich enough in Metal, to be wrought with good profit. And yet thee hard and heavy (Mineral) Stones are very far from being homogeneous; ince I have met with few Inanimate Bodies, produced by Nature her elf, o compounded as everal Marcaites that I have een. For thee are wont to contain
more or les Copper, and Iron too: and they abound in Combutible Sulphur, a Corroive Salt, and a certain Fixt Subtance, which I found to differ from true Earth, but of whoe Nature the Tryals I have hitherto made on it, have but little atisfied me.

I might here deduce the Poroity of the Load-tone, as hard and olid a Body as it is, partly from the Effluvia it emits and admits, and partly from the Heterogeneity I have by Chymical Tryals found to be in it. But thee things belong more properly to a Paper about Magnetical Bodies, for which I the more willingly reerve them, becaue other Experiments will keep them from being needful to be here inited on.

The Poroity of Marble, and divers other Stones of like Contexture, may with probability be deduc'd from this, that they are liable to be diolved by divers of the corroive Mentruums of the Chymits, uch as Aqua fortis p. of Salt, &c. And ome of them even by Vegetable Liquors, of Natures own
preparing, as the juice of Limons, and that of Barberries. But a more noble and atisfactory intance may be afforded, by the invention of taining or colouring white Marble, without imploying any fretting Liquor, or poiling the Texture of it. This way being caually lighted on by an ingenious Stone-cutter in Oxford, who gained by it both credit and money, he long ince thought fit to acquaint me with it, upon condition of ecrey (which I have to this day inviolably kept) and of my aiting him to improve his Invention by making it practicable with other Colours than Red. Thee circumtances I mention, to ignify that I write not by gues, of this matter, having both een the Experiment tried, and made it my elf. But though I found it far les improvable to other ues, then one would expect, yet, as to our preent purpoe, it is very appoite. For by this way an excellent red Colour, may be made to oak into a piece of White Marble, almot as Oyl will do into Leather, without
impairing, that I oberved, the olidity of the tone, which, after being dyed, will be capable of a fine glos as before. Some other Colours (yet but few fair ones) would by this way be brought to oak into Marble, on which one may with them o define, and limit the Colorations, that I remember the Artificer, when I brought him to kis the Kings hand, preented His Majety with an Andromeda, whoe Colours were o vivid, that this skilful Judge of curious things, was pleaed to honour it with a place among his Rarities. And, to atisfy his Majety that the fine Red was not, as ome upected, a mere varnih, I purpoely broke a plate of Marble, in whoe fragments he aw, that the Pigment had unk to a coniderable depth, into the very Subtance of the Stone. And I doubt not but it might have been made eaily enough to ink much deeper, if it had been thought neceary. A fine Plate of uch White Marble, with the penetrating Pictures of Coloured Flowers drawn upon it I
yet keep by me to atisfy the curious. And ome Utenils, as Hafts of Knives, Salt-Sellers, &c. I have known to have lated everal years.

There is an Experiment that eems much tronger for the Porounes of Solid Bodies, than that it elf (which was lately recited) of taining Marble. For in Italy ome Goldmiths have a way of imbuing Fragments of Rock-Crytal, which is a Body much harder than Marble, with divers Colours; which do ometimes o imbellih them, that having ground off thoe parts that would not receive the ame Tincture, they et ome of them in Gold Rings, and ell them with profit. When I was inform'd of this, I thought of a Compoition, that I hop'd might perform the ame thing, and perhaps better than that which was employ'd by them, who either knew not, or for ought I could perceive, us'd not, ome Minerals that I thought fit for the purpoe. Upon this Preumption we carefully cemented ome clear Fragments of Native Crytal with a
Compoition of ome Volatile Minerals, together with a Salt or two, and having uffered the Crucibles to cool leiurely, we had divers of the Fragments tain'd here and there, ome with one Colour and ome with another, as differing Fumes happen'd to invade them. And of thee Colours ome were dark or dull, and ome vivid enough. But having conider'd the tain'd pieces, and the progres of the Operation, more attentively, I began to doubt, whether thee Adventitious Colours were really produced by the bare penetrating of the Mineral Fumes into the Pores of the Crytal it elf. For I thought it poible, and not very unprobable, that the great Heat of the Fire, and the Ambient Mixture, might cleave or flaw in many places ome of the Crytalline Fragments; and that the finer parts of the Minerals being vehemently agitated, might ininuate themelves into thee thin Flaws, which upon the low refrigeration of the Stones, hutting themelves cloe again, might
lock up the tinging Particles, without appearing dicontinued, epecially to the Eyes of Perons that were not made ue of with a more than ordinary attention, excited by ditrut. This upicion was not removed by the apparent entirenes of each little piece of Crytal. For having taken more than once a Lump of that tone, and lowly brought it to be red hot in the Fire, I found that if I warily quenched it in Water, though it would thereby acquire a multitude of little cracks or Flaws, which detroyed its former tranparency, and made it look whitih, yet it continued till an entire Body, notwithtanding the diadvantageous hate, wherewith the operation had been performed. And having after this upicion, inquired of an ingenious Lapidary, that belonged to a great Prince whether in polihing of Gems upon the Wheel, he had taken notice that the Heat would flaw them, he anwered me, that now and then he had oberved that ome Stones, epecially if I miremember not, Rubies, when
they were very much heated by the wift motion of the Engine he employed to polih them, did cleave as it eemed to him, and gape, o as at firt to make him fear the Stones were poiled; and yet afterwards they cloed o perfectly, that no Flaw at all could be perceived in them. I have mentioned the foregoing Experiment of tinging Crytal, to comply with the dictates of Philoophical candor, which forbids me to lay much tres upon a Proof, whoe validity I my elf ditrut. But perhaps my upicion may by further Tryal, which I have not now conveniency to make, appear not to have been well grounded, and in that cae the tinging of Crytal, as well inwardly as outwardly, by Fumes will be a noble Argument for the Poroity of Solid Bodies, Rock-Crytal being harder, and probably cloer, not only than Marble, but even than Glas.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p: THat Metals, though the heaviet of Bodies, are not detitute of Pores, may be with probability proved in a general way by this; That they are all dioluble in their appropriate Mentruums, as Gold in Aqua Regia, and all the ret in Aqua Fortis, except Tin, which yet it elf will be corroded by that Mentruum, though not well kept up in a fluid form, as it may be by another Mentruum, which I elewhere teach; and ometimes the ame Metal may be diolved by very differing Mentruums, as Lead by Aqua fortis, and Spirit of Vinegar; and Copper by Aqua fortis, Aqua Regia, Spirit of Vinegar, Spirit of Salt, and ome other Solvents, that upon Trial I have found ufficient for that purpoe.

But 'twill, I preume, be thought more coniderable to my preent argument, if it be hewn, that Bodies that appear Gros, and which in their Natural tate are not fluid, and are
confeed to be of a compounded nature, will penetrate Metals quite through, even without melting them.

This we have divers times effected by a Cementation of Copper Plates, With common (much a kin to a way precribed by ome Alchymits to make Vitriolum Veneris) which we warily performed much after this manner. We took good Copper laminated to the thicknes of a Shilling or thereabouts, and having cut it into mall pieces, that they might the more eaily be put into a Crucible or Cementing Pot, we trewed at the bottom of the Veel ome beaten , and then covered it pretty well with ome of thee Plates, which were laid on flat-wie. Upon thee we trewed another Bed of powdered Brimtone, and cover'd that alo with Plates, upon which we put more Sulphur, & o continu'd making one lair of Brimtone, & another of Metal, till we had employed all our Plates, or filled the Crucible, being careful that the uppermot Bed, as well as the lowet, hould be of Sulphur.
This done, we luted on an earthen Cover to the Veel, to keep the from taking Fire, and afterwards having placed the Pot amongt Coals kindled at a good ditance from it, that it might be heated by degrees, we kept it for ome few hours (perhaps Two or Three) in uch a degree of Fire as was ufficient to keep the Sulphur melted (which is eaily enough done) without bringing the Metal to fuion; the Pot being cold, we took off the cover, and found the Plates quite altered in Colour and Texture, ome of them having a dark and dirty Colour, whilt others looked of a fine Violet or Blew; they were generally o brittle, that 'twas very eay to break them with ones finger, and reduce them to Powder. And (now to add uch Circumtances as a Chymit would not take notice of) many of the Plates, when they were broken, appeared to have been (by the contiguous Beds of Sulphur above and below) horizontally divided each of them into two
Plates, divers of which in ome places had a manifet ditance or Cavity between them. And 'twas obervable, that when I conidered one or other of thee Plates attentively in the parts that had been contiguous before I broke it, I could plainly dicern a multitude as 'twere of Fibres, reaching from one of the flat ides of the Plate to the other, & running many of them, as to ene, parallel to one another. Thee Circumtances may ufficiently argue, that the Plates were pierced quite through by the Brimtone; but for confirmation of this, and to hew too that the Sulphur does as it were oak into the Body of the Metal, and in a Gros manner lodge it elf there; I hall add, that not only to the Eye the Plates appeared much welled, or thicker then when they were put in, but having weighed them before the operation was begun, and after it was quite ended, the Copper, though it needed not to be freed from externally adhering Sulphur, was found to have a coniderable increae of weight by
the acceion of the Sulphur, which (to add that circumtance) though it appeared not to the Eye, yet if a Plate were laid upon quick Coles, and blown, would oftentimes dicover it elf by a Blew flame.

By making the like Experiment for the main, we found that refined Silver, though a more heavy and compact Body, than Copper, and not dioluble by mot of the Mentruums, that work on this Metal, is penetrable by the Body of Sulphur, which will alo calcine Tin and Lead and (epecially) Iron.

Nor is Sulphur the only conitent Body that has this ingres into Metals; for we have found them penetrable by prepared Arenick. But becaue thee operations are not o eay, and the Subject is not eaily handled without danger, I forbear the mention of them in this place, where, after what has been recited, it is not neceary.

Another Experiment there is,
which does more advantageouly than that made with Brimtone, dicover the Poroity of Copper. For there is a way by which, without the help of Salts, Sulphur or Arenick, one may make a olid and heavy Body oak into the Pores of that Metal, and give it a durable Colour. I hall not mention the way, becaue of the bad ue that may be made of it. But having had the curioity more than once to try it upon a new Copper Farthing, the event was, that one part of it, which I purpoely forbore to tinge, remained common Copper till, but the other part acquired a yellow, that differed very little, if at all, from a Golden Colour, the former tamp that was impreed upon the coin continuing viible. And to convince the crupulous, that the Pigment did really ink, and as it were oak into the Body of the Metal, and did not meerly colour the Superficies, I made them take notice, that the Farthing was not melted, and yet by filing off a wide gap from the Edge of the Coin, inwards, it plainly
appeared, that the Yellow or Golden Colour had penetrated a pretty way beneath the urface of the Farthing; o that it looked there as if two thin Plates, the one Yellow, and the other Reddih, did, without any Interval between them, lye upon one another.

If Bodies be not to be pervaded, or deeply pierced into, by Corpucles, but only to have their more uperficial Pores, if I may o call them, penetrated thereby, 'tis poible that Bodies, which are either much harder, or much cloer, than Marble, Alabater or the like Bodies, may have their Pores poeed even by odorous Corpucles; I ay, even by uch, becaue they are mot of them gros enough to be kept from exhaling, by Bodies much les compact then Earthen Bottles; and are far from being of the finet particles that Nature affords. But that uch odorous Corpucles may lodge themelves in the exterior Pores of very cloe Bodies, I have been inclined to think, not only, by the obtinately
adhering Odour, which I found by Tryal, that ome uttle and Spirituous parts, uch as the Chymits would perhaps call in their Aggregates, the Eence of Musk, Amber, Amber-greece, &c. notwithtanding the wahing of the Glaes, that had long contained uch Liquors; but by what has been aured me by a Phyician of great Experience, who travelled and lived much in the Eat. For having told him, that I had been informed, that in ome places les famous then Damacus, for curioity in making fine Sword blades, there was a way found and practied of making them richly cented, without injury to their Glos; I deired to know of him, if at Damacus, or elewhere, he had een any of them; to which he replied, that he did not remember he had, but yet made no doubt the Information might be true. For he himelf had in Europe, and kept for divers years, a Watch, whoe Metalline Cae, was richly perfumed; and when I askt him, whether there were not ome
thin varnih, or ome outward Cae of perfumed Leather, or Chagran, or omewhat ele, from whence the odour proceeded, he aured me, that his obervations had prevented and removed that and divers other Scruples, and that the cae being clean and Gloy, he could not perceive that the Odour proceeded from any thing ele, than ome odoriferous thing, or other that was inviibly lodged in the Pores, or Porous Subtance of the metal it elf. And indeed, ince both Arenick, and even common Sulphur, may by Art be as it were incorporated with ome Metalls, and even with Silver, I ee not why it hould be impoible, that ome pleaingly cented Subtances hould be admitted into the Pores of Metalline Bodies, and be volatile enough to have their ubtiler parts fly off in odorous Exhalations, epecially if they be a little excited, as the Watch Cae lately mentioned was, by a gentle heat, uch as was that of the
wearers pocket. And on this occaion I remember to have made a certain Metalline compoition, which looked like Gold, and of which I caued a Ring to be cat, and yet this Metal retained o many unperceived Mercurial Corpucles in it, that an Ingenious Peron to whom I dicovered the compoition of it, found after Tryal, as he aured me, that being worn as a Ring, it had in ome ditempers, particularly of the Eyes, manifet operations, that evidently enough eemed to flow, at leat in great part, from its participation of the Mercury we employed in preparing the Factitious Metal.

Since the writing of the former part of this Eay, having met with an inquiitive Nobleman, who had lived in everal parts of Africk, and was Governour of the bet Town the Europeans have on that Continent, I dicoured with him, among other things, about the Skill that ome acribe to the African Moors, of making excellent weapons, whereof I knew his excellency
was very curious. Upon which occaion he told me, that ome of the Off-Spring of the Granadine Moors were indeed the bet at making Arms that ever he met with; and that he had een ome weapons of their forging and tempering, that he preferred even to thoe of Damaco. And when I asked him whether any of them had the art of perfuming their Weapons, he anwered me, that ome of them did it admirably well, and intanced in a Blade which he kept for ome years, & found it till to retain the perfumed cent, which he uppoed to be as it were incorporated with the Steel whereof the Blade was made. When I told him, I upected that the cabbard might have been well perfumed, and communicate its odour to the contained Blade, he allowed the objection to be plauible, but replyed that it was not concluding, ince miliking the Scabbard, as not handom & fahionable enough, he caued a new one to be made, wherein he afterwards kept it. And the ame Lord further
told me, that he had alo a Fowling Piece, whoe Barrel was perfumed. And when I objected that perhaps the odoriferous cent proceeded from the tock, and not from the Metal, he anwered that the Gun not being, when it came into his poeion, skilfully and handomely mounted, he caued the Barrel to be fitted with a new tock, notwithtanding which, it continued to mell fragrantly. And when I further asked, whether he ever caued the Gun to be wahed or coured after it was grown foul by having been often hot in, he anwered me, that he had, and, as far as I can remember, ubjoyned, that after it was made clean it did (notwithtanding the ill cent that the oot of the Powder had given it) retain a pleaing mell, but fainter than before.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
div.p: SInce the Subject of this Eay is the Porounes of Solid Bodies, and ince there is no Body that is generally reputed o cloe and compact as Glas, it will be pertinent to this dicoure, and probably will be expected, that I hould here ay omething about the Quetion, whether Glas be, or be not, devoid of Pores.

But before I acquaint you with my Tryals, or my thoughts, about this Problem, I think it requiite to clear the ene, in which I mean to handle it, that I may not, as ome others have done, for want of ditinctly tating the Quetion, peak confuedly and erroneouly of it.

I hall then here oberve, to prevent mitakes, that the Poroity of Glas may admit of two Acceptions. For it may be aid to be quite pervious to
Fluids, as a Boot is to Water, or only to be capable of having its uperficial parts further and further diolved or corroded thereby, as a Silver Cup is Porous in reference to Aqua fortis, which cannot weat through it, as Water does through a Boot, but eat its way through it, by diolving the Texture of the Veel.

Another thing requiite to be premied, to prevent Ambiguity, is, that Glas it elf is not all of one ort, as men unacquainted with Chymitry are wont to preume, for Glas of Antimony, for intance, and that of Lead, both of them made per e, do manifetly differ, uually in colour, and contantly in weight, and alo in their operations upon Humane Bodies; and both thee orts of Glas do in everal points differ from common Glas, under which name, for brevities ake, I comprehend both White or Crytalline Glas, as 'tis called in the Shops, and that courer ort, which they uually call Green Glas; both which orts I here conider under one Notion, becaue
both are made of fixt Alcalies, and other fit Ingredients, as Sand, Earth, Ahes, Pebbles, or Flints, Colliquated by a trong & lating operation of the Fire: and 'tis of this common Glas, in the ene now declared, that I hall conider the Poroity in the remaining part of this Eay. In which to proceed with ome Method, I hall diget what I have to ay into the enuing Propoitions, and the obervations annext to them.
div.q: Prop 1. 'Tis very probable, that Glas may be pierced into to ome ditance, even by viible and tangible Bodies.
div.p:
I know that this will eem a Paradox to many, and repugnant to common Experience, which hews that Glas Veels will contain very ubtile and even highly corroive Liquors, as the Spirit of Harthorn, of Urine, and that of Nitre; as alo thoe potent Mentruums, as Aqua fortis, Aqua Regis, and Oil of Vitriol,
which not only are not oberved to pierce into it, but are unable to make any enible alteration, o much as on the uperficial parts, even in thoe Vials wherein they have been long kept.

But, notwithtanding all this, I preume you will not condemn the lately propoed Paradox, when you have conidered what may be aid to jutifie it. For, beides that it may be made probable à Priori, by the Arguments whence we have formerly proved the Porounes of Solid Bodies in general; there are two orts of Experiments, from whence one may argue, that Glas in particular is not devoid of Pores in the ene wherein we are now peaking of them.

And firt, I remember, that, having kept for a good while in a vial, a quantity of a certain Spirit of Salt, that I had reerved in a cool place; I found, when I came to ue it, that the Glas was crackt, and mot of the Liquor was run out; but, before this
happened, it had o far corroded the inide of the Glas, that in ome places it was eaten almot as thin as a piece of Paper; and this part which yet continued Glas, was lin'd with a much thicker white ubtance, that tuck to the ides of it, and looked and tated like a kind of odd Salt; o that it invited me to conjecture, that it proceeded from the ubtance of the Glas, which you know conits of an Alcali as well as of Sand corroded by the Saline Spirits of the Mentruum, and coagulated with them into this odd kind of Concrete; and 'twas remarkable in our veel, that the upper part of the vial, to which the Mentruum did not reach, was not corroded, nor alter'd, tho the operation of the Liquor reached as high as the Liquor it elf. And I remember, that when I related all this to ome experienced Chymits, one of them that was a more heedful oberver, aured me, the like had once or twice, happened to him, as ince that time it hath likewie done to me.

I had alo, if I miremember not, another Vial, corroded by a ditilled Liquor of Vitriol, that had in it more of the Phlegm than of the Oil; which you will omewhat the les wonder at, if you conider, that ome Corroive Mentruums will carce work on ome Bodys, if they be too well dephlegmed, or at leat will not corrode them o readily and powerfully, if they are very trong, as when they are diluted with a convenient quantity of Water. And, as to Oil of Vitriol it elf, which is the Mentruum I am peaking of, when we employ it to make Vitriolum Martis, we are wont to weaken it with Water, that it may the better diolve that Metal. And perhaps you will upect, that Vitriol has ome peculiar faculty of penetrating and fretting Glas, when to the Experiment newly recited I hall add that which follows, as I find it regitred among my Notes.

[A pound of Dantzick Vitriol and a pound of Sea Salt, after the former had been very lightly calcined, and the
latter decrepitated, that they might not boil in, or crack the Veel; we caued to be ditilled in a well coated Retort by degrees of Fire, giving at length a very trong one, then taking off the Veel, we were not much urprized to find, that the heat had here and there melted it, and that the fluxed Caput Mortuum had corroded the Glas, fetching off as 'twere films from it, and thoe parts which did not appear to the Eye thus manifetly wated, eemed yet by their great brittlenes, to have been penetrated, o that their Texture was poiled by the aline and vitriolate Corpucles.]
div.q: Prop II. Common Glas is not ordinarily permeable by Chymical Liquors, though trong and ubtile, nor by the directly viible or odorable Expirations of Bodies tho abolutely peaking it be pervious to ome Corporeal Subtances.
div.p: This Propoition coniting of two parts, we hall allow each of them its ditinct Proofs.

And as for the firt part, 'tis manifetly
agreeable to the Common Experience of Chymits; who daily find, that in well topt Vials, or at leat in Hermetically eal'd Glaes, they can preerve their ubtilet and mot piercing Mentruums, as Spirit of Nitre, Aqua Fortis, Spirit of Salt, Spirit of Vinegar, and Oil of Vitriol. And this they find to be true, not only as to Acid and Corroive Liquors, like thoe I have newly named, but alo in thoe Spirits that abound with Fugitive Salts, as the Spirit of Urine, of Blood, and of Sal-Armoniack; and in the mot ubtile & highly rectified Spirit of Wine; as alo in the Ethereal Oil, or, as many call it, Spirit, of Turpentine: as likewie in the Liquors of Salt of Tartar, and other fixt Alcalies reolved by Deliquium.

The Reult of thee Obervations may be much confirmed by conidering, how often it happens in the Detillation of more Wild and Fugitive Spirits, as of Nitre, Tartar, and Sugar; that, though they
are much agitated, and perhaps ubtilized, by Heat, yet, if the Lute, that joins the Receiver to the Retort be very firm & cloe, the Receivers, though large, are often broken in pieces; which probably would not happen, if the Spirits could ininuate & croud themelves, through the pores of Glas.

But, whereas it may be pretended, that uch Veels are trong and thick, I hall add, that I have had the Curioity to caue very fine bubbles to be blown at the flame of a Lamp, purpoly that they may be made extreamly thin, and of but a mall part of the thicknes we meet with in the Veels made at the Glas houe; and ome of thee I caus'd to be exactly topt, and others to be Hermetically eal'd; but could not find, that either dry Salt of Tartar would relent in one, that was kept a good while under water, or that trong Spirit of Sal Armoniack, which is one of the ubtilet Spirits that we know, would penetrate one of thee thin films of Glas, which we kept
a great while immered in it, though to dicover whether it would at all penetrate the thinnet Glaes, we employed ome which were of that fine ort that is called Eence Vials.

Thee and ome other Tryals have, I confes, made me very diffident of the Experiments, that have been delivered by ome men of Note, and built upon by others, of the Permeablenes of ordinary Glas Veels to Chymical Liquors, as, that Mercury and Aqua fortis being digeted together in a Bolt-head may, by rubbing the outide of the Glas, be made viibly and palpably to tranudate. Which Experiment (if my Memory do not much deceive me,) I purpoely tryed with care, but without ucces.

But after all this I mut deire, that it may be remembred, that in wording the Propoition of the Imperviounes of Glas, I intimated that I would have it undertood of what Ordinarily happens. For in ome Extraordinary caes, which I take to be exceeding rare, I do not abolutely
deny, but that the General rule may admit of Exceptions. And, if it be lawful to conjecture, thee exceptions are likeliet to take place, when the peculiar Texture of this or that Glas, is more light or lax than ordinary; or when the Bodies that are to pervade it, are vehemently agitated by heat; or when, beides a great ubtlety, and perhaps degree of heat too, their particles chance to have a pecial congruity, to the relaxed Pores of that particular Glas they are to pas through. I remember I have een, not without ome wonder, a ort of Glas of o oft and reoluble a Texture, that Veels of it of a competent thicknes, would be manifetly prejudiced and wrought upon by Liquors, that were not coniderably Sharp or Corroive, if they were put in very hot. I have alo heard of another ort of Glaes, made in a certain Forret, complained of by a Detiller, as ubject to be ometimes injured by Corroive Liquors. I once knew a Doctor of Phyick, that by divers credulous Alchymits was upected
to have, what they call the Philoophers Stone, becaue of a certain Book, Ingenious enough, that he was uppoed to have written on that ubject. But when after ome acquaintance I happened to debate his Principles freely with him, he confeed to me, that he had been mitaken, and to invite me to give him my thoughts upon uch like works, he frankly made me an ingenuous relation of his Proceedings, wherein the main thing that dazled him, and kept him from eeing his Error, was, that he had reduced the matter he wrought on, which was real Gold, to that degree of Fuiblenes and ubtlety, that when he gave too trong a Fire, as mitake or curioity made him everal times do, the finer part of the Metal would weat through his Glaes, and tick ometimes to the outide of them, and ometimes to the Neighbouring Bodies. And, when I objected, that he might be mitaken in this, and that what he thought had come forth by tranudation, rather iued out at ome
mall unheeded crack, he replyed that he had made the obervation o often, and with uch care, that he was fully atisfied it was a real penetration of the Glas, by the attenuated Metal, which he was to have convinced me of by Tryal. But, before he could come to make it, by an Errour of his own he unhappily died.

But, whatever be judged of this penetrating Gold, I elewhere relate, that I having upon a time detilled Spirit of Harts-horn with a very trong Fire, into a Receiver that was large and thick enough, but of a coure kind of Glas, it did appear, upon my bet examination, that the Glas itelf was penetrated by ome vehemently agitated Fumes, or ome ubtile Liquor, that etled in trongly cented drops on the outide of the Receiver. But uch Intances being very rare, and happening but in ome caes or conjunctures of circumtances, that are not like to be at all frequent, they cannot hinder the firt part of our Propoition to be true, in
the ene wherein 'tis laid down.

And, as to the econd part of the Propoition, which aerts Glas to be pervious to ome Corporeal ubtances, it may be proved ad hominem againt any Epicurean that hould deny it, and the Carteians mut not) by the free ingres and egres, which our eal'd Thermocopes hew, that the Atoms or Corpucles of Cold and Heat are allowed, through the Pores of the Glas, that contains the riing or fallng Tincture, or other Liquor. And without proceeding upon the peculiar Principles of the Epicureans, we may give more certain proofs of the Permeablenes of Glas by certain Bodies. For I have elewhere manifetly evinced that the Effluvia of a Loadtone will attract and invigorate Steel, though incloed in Hermetically eal'd Glaes; nay, I have alo hewn by Experiment, that the Effluvia of o gros and dull a Body as the Earth, are readily tranmitted through Glas, and will operate on Iron, in Veels hermetically ealed. If Light be, as probably
'tis, either a ubtile and rapidly moving Body, or at leat require uch an one for its Vehicle, it mut not be denied, that 'tis poible for a Body without difficulty to pas through the Pores of Glas; ince 'tis by its help that we can clearly ee the Dimenions, Shapes, and Colours of Bodies included in Glaes. To this I hall add, that far les ubtile Bodies than thoe that contitute or convey Light, may be made to permeate Glas, if their Figures being congruous enough to the Pores of it, their penetration be aited by an impetuous motion, or a brisk impule; as I have found by the increae of weight in ome Metals, expoed for divers hours in Hermetically eal'd Glaes, to the action of a Flame. On which occaion I remember that having ome years ago tryed the ame Experiment with ome Filings of Copper, they had indeed their colour much alter'd, being beautified with exceeding vivid Dyes, which they yet retain, but did not evidently appear to be increaed in weight, as if, becaue
they were not of a Texture looe enough to be melted, the Igneous particles could not pierce them enough to tick fat in them, at leat in numbers great enough, to amount to a enible weight.

But without the help of Fire, or any enible Heat, I think it not impoible that Glas hould be freely penetrated by ome kind of Corpucles, (though I do not yet know of what ort they are) that ometimes happen to roave about in the Air. This you will probably be urprized to read; but perhaps not more than I was at the Phaenomena that induce me to write it. But becaue thee are very unuual, and can carce be dicoured of without ome odd reflections hinted by them, I thought fit to et down a Circumtantial account of them in another Paper, to which it more directly belongs than to this Eay; and therefore hall now only tell you, what may be ufficient for my preent purpoe, namely, that having in two or three Vials cloely topt, kept a certain limpid and colourles
Liquor, it would by fits acquire and loe a high Colour, though I could not reaonably impute the Changes to any manifet ones in the Air, nor to any other caue o probable, as the Ingres and Reces of ome very ubtle and uncommon particles, which at that time happened to wim to and fro in the Air, and now and then to invade, and ometimes to deert, the Liquor.

There is another ort of Experiments relating to the Poroity of Glas, to hew that it may be pierced into by Bodies that are not corroive in tat, and are not Liquors, but only have a forced and temporary Fluidity, if they have o much as that.

Thee Experiments may be drawn from ome of the ways of colouring Panes of Glas, for the Windows of Churches and other buildings; I ay, ome of the ways, becaue, to deal candidly with you, I think, and o I preume will you ere long, that in divers of thoe Glaes, the Colour doth not pierce at all deep into the Glas,
but is produced by the cloe adheion of a deep Red, but thin and tranparent, Pigment, to the urface of a Glay Plate, through both which the Beams of Light paing to the Eye, receive in their Paage the colour of the Pigment.

But, as by ome operations the Glas is rather Painted, or externally enamelled, than tinged, o in ome others the Pigment or dying tuff appears to pierce a little beneath the very uperficies of the Glas, and the Yellow Colour will not only go further or deeper, but ometimes eems (for I do not yet poitively affirm it) to penetrate the whole Glas from ide to ide.

The Methods of Painting and taining Glas, having been hitherto the Practices of a particular Trade that is gainful enough, and known but to few, the Artificers are wont to be hy of communicating their ecrets, thô we know in general that Glas is tained, by having the Plates covered with Mineral Pigments, laid on Beds of
beaten Lime, or ome other convenient Powder, and kept for divers Hours in a trong fire, but yet not trong enough to make the Plates melt down, by which means the Pores of the Glas being much opened by the Heat, and the Pigments being likewie agitated, and ome of them as it were vitrified with it, they are made either to pierce into the Plate, or at leat to tick very cloely and firmly to it. But becaue the Practices of Glas Painters require, beides skill and experience, a particular Furnace, and divers Implements, I hall add, that to try, whether Glas may not, without o much ado, be o tained, as to hew it to be Porous, we took prepared Silver, (that Metal having, of all the Minerals I have tryed, the bet Ingres into Glas) and having laid it upon a piece of Glas, not thick, nor yet o thin as to Melt very eaily, we laid this Glas (with the Pigment uppermot) warily upon a few Quick-coals, and having uffered it to neal a while we gave it about uch a degree of heat, as might
make and keep it red hot, without bringing it to compleat fuion, and then, uffering it to cool by degrees, we found, as we expected, that the Glas had acquired a Yellow, and almot Golden, Colour, which was not to be wahed off, or to be taken away, without uch craping as would injure or poil the Glas it elf. The way of preparing Silver for this operation, is not always the ame, the Glas Painters commonly add to the calcined Silver ome Mineral Bodies, as Antimony, Yellow Oker, or the like. But I, who take the penetration of the colour to proceed from the Silver it elf, do ometimes imploy only ome thin piece of Silver, uch as an old Groat, upon which a little Sulphur being put, and kindled in the open Air, the Metal is preently calcined, and the Powder made ue of. And this it elf I do not o much out of neceity, as becaue the Calcination reduces the Metal into mall parts, and gives it a form, that makes it more eay be laid on, as one thinks fit. For
otherwie, going upon this my uppoition, that the Silver was the true Pigment of the Glas, I have more than once made Glas Yellow by Leaf-Silver laid flat on the urface of it, and a little moitened, to keep o light a Body from being blown off. And (to note that upon the by) 'tis pretty, that if the Fire be made too trong, which 'tis hard to avoid doing, when we will make it trong enough, without the help of a Furnace, it has everal times happened to me that the dyed Glas, though when held againt the Light it appeared of a Golden or Yellow Colour, yet when held from the Light it appeared Blew, o that here we have in a Mineral, omewhat that is very like that we admire in the tincture of Lignum Nephriticum, which hews almot the like difference of Colour, as 'tis held againt or from the Light, which may erve for a confirmation of what I have elewhere aid to hew that colours may be derived from Mechanical Principles: But that only upon the by. Whether the Gold
colour produced by Silver, do favour the hopes of thoe Alchymits that work on that Metal, upon preumption that 'tis but unripe Gold, 'tis improper here to examine. But ince Yellow is not the Colour of Silver, it eems the Yellownes, acquired by our Glas Plates, argues, that there has been ome ingres of the ubtance of the particles of the Silver into the Glas, there appearing no way o ready, to give an account of the change of Colours, as by uppoing the Particles of the Silver to be wrought on by the fixt Salts, and other fine parts, of the Glas; ince we know, that Metals may afford differing colours, according to the Saline and other Bodies that work upon them, as Copper with Spirit of Urine, which abounds in Volatile Salt, gives a deep Blew; with Spirit of Salt, a fair Green; and with Aqua fortis, a Colour that participates of both. And in the making of Glas of Lead with Minium and White-Sand, or Crytal, the Glas, it elf if well made, is uually of an Amethytine Colour. But
if you put a due Proportion, (which is a very mall one,) of calcined Copper to it, this Metal will not communicate to the Glas its own reddihnes, but be o changed by it, as to give it a good green, and ometimes o good an one, that pieces of this Glas, uch as we have caued to be cut and et in Rings, might, among thoe that Judge of Stones but by the Eye, pas for no bad Emeraulds.

On this occaion, 'tis likely 'twill be asked, whether there be any way of tinging Glaes quite through, with a true and beautiful red, and whether the Art of dying Plates of Glas, which the windows of many old Churches hew to have formerly been practied, be now (as 'tis commonly uppoed) altogether lot?

This Quetion, coniting of 2 Parts, I hall quickly dipatch; the former, by anwering it without heitancy in the affirmative. Yet adding withal, that the red tincture being communicated to Glas, not properly by mere penetration of the Pigment, but by the incorporation
of it with Glas or its Materials, by the help of fuion, I think the Experiment of no uch great ue in our preent Inquiry, as to hinder me from reerving what I have oberved about it to a more opportune place. And as to the econd Part of the inquiry, it being rather a Hitorical than a Philoophical quetion, I hall not here meddle with it; only I hall wih the quetion may be cautiouly tated. For, upon the burning the famous Cathedral of St. Pauls Church in London, many pieces of the red Glas that adorned the windows, were found broken and cattered about, ome of which I procur'd from a Chymit, that had carefully preerved them, deigning to retrieve the lot Invention of making the like. But when I came to examine them narrowly, I was confirmed in the upicion I had, that the rednes did not penetrate the whole Glas, but proceeded from a diaphanous Pigment very artificially laid on, for though in other Potures no uch thing could be dicerned, yet
when I o held it, according to my Cutom in examining painted Glaes, that the urfaces of the Plate lay in the ame level with my Eye, between it and the window, o that a broken edge was next my Eye, I could plainly ee, and made the Chymit himelf ee, the lower part of the Plate to be of ordinary uncoloured Glas, upon which there lay a very thin Plate or Bed of a Diaphanous red Pigment, which, though it were not eaily, was not impoible to be here and there craped off.

But, to return to thoe colorations that eem to pierce into the Pores of Glas, I remember that I had once occaion to detil in a mall Retort ome Gold, amalgamed with uch a fine and ubtile Mercury, that being (without the addition of any Salt) put to the Gold in the cold, they preently grew hot together. And in the detillation of this uncommon mixture, I found the matter had, before it flew a way, permanently died or tained, about an Inch in Diameter of the bottom of the
Glas, with a colour that, looked on from the Light, was like that of the better ort of Turquoies; but beheld when 'twas interpoed between the Window and the Eye, appeared of a omewhat Golden colour. And this Glas, with ome others oddly colored, I have yet by me to atisfy the Curious, though I cannot but give Advertiement, that the colorations of Glas may be much better performed with uch Plates, and in uch Furnaces, as the Glas Painters ue, than without them.

Since the Writing of the foregoing Paragraph, I was viited by an indutrious peron, much addicted to ome Chymical Operations, who had formerly advied with me about a Proces, of which I had had ome Experience, that he conceived might be ueful to him. I then acquainted him with ome of my thoughts about it, and he having afterwards united Gold with Quick-Silver, (which by its Effects will be eaily concluded not to have been common,) he kept them in Digetion
for ome Months, & afterwards coming to me with a Melancholy look, told me that the Fire having been once immoderately increaed in his abence, the ealed-Glas burt with an affrighting noie, and the included Amalgam was o trangely diipated, that carce the let fragment of it could be retrieved. But the Decoction having continued o long a time, it eems the matter was ubtiliated enough to have a notable operation upon the Glas. For, though the upper part of the Bolt-glas were blown of, and hattered into many pieces, yet the lower part caped well enough, and when he brought it me, to oberve what change had been made in it, I took notice with much delight, that the Glas eemed to be tinged throughout, with o fine and glorious a Red colour, that I have een everal Rubies themelves, in that point, inferiour to it.
